    Inoperable vehicle means any vehicle which is not registered or which is improperly registered within the state, or is not displaying proper license plates, or is inoperable for more than seventy-two (72) hours. 
    Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation or other organization of any kind. 
    Property means any land owned by the city or located within the city limits, not including streets and highways. 
    Street or highway means the entire area between the boundary lines of every publicly maintained way when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Vehicles means any machine propelled by power other than human power designed to travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners or slides, including but not limited to automobiles, trucks, trailers, motorcycles, tractors, buggies, wagons or any part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 731, § 1, 7-24-89; Ord. No. 4517, art. 4, 12-2-13) 
Sec. 13-52. - Nuisance declared. 
    Except as provided in other regulations, any inoperable vehicle or part thereof, located on any property in the city is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 731, § 1, 7-24-89; Ord. No. 2805, art. 1, 10-23-00; Ord. No. 4517, art. 4, 12-2-13) 
Sec. 13-53. - Maintenance of nuisance prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to create or maintain a nuisance as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 731, § 1, 7-24-89) 
Sec. 13-54. - Notice. 
    Whenever the chief of police or his duly authorized representative determines that any vehicle is a nuisance under this division, he shall cause written notice to be served upon the owner of the vehicle, if he can be located, or the person in custody of such vehicle, by registered mail or by personal service. The notice shall state that the vehicle is deemed to be a nuisance within the provisions of section 13-52, and shall briefly state facts deemed to constitute such vehicle a nuisance within the terms of this division, and state that the nuisance shall be abated within seven (7) days from receipt of such notice. 
(Ord. No. 770, § 1, 10-16-89) 
Sec. 13-55. - Proceedings when owner or custodian cannot be located. 
    When the owner or custodian of any nuisance under this division cannot be located by reasonable search, the notice shall be attached to the vehicle, briefly stating facts deemed to constitute a nuisance and stating that the nuisance shall be abated within seven (7) days of the date notice was posted. 
(Ord. No. 770, § 2, 10-16-89) 
Sec. 13-56. - Duty of the owner or custodian. 
    Any person receiving the notice provided for in section 13-55 shall comply with the provisions of the notice requiring abatement. Failure to comply with this provision is unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 731, § 1, 7-24-89) 
Sec. 13-57. - Disposition. 
    If not removed within the time specified in the notice, the vehicle determined to be a nuisance under this division shall be transported to a storage area by or at the direction of the chief of police or his duly authorized representative at the expense of the owner or persons in custody thereof. Unclaimed vehicles are to be disposed of in accordance with this Code and city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 731, § 1, 7-24-89) 
Sec. 13-58. - Entry onto private property. 
    The chief of police or his duly authorized representative may enter upon private property for inspection or for the purpose of removing any vehicle in accordance with this division. If any person refuses to allow entry onto his private property, the chief of police may obtain a warrant from the proper official and proceed in accordance therewith. 
(Ord. No. 731, § 1, 7-24-89) 
Sec. 13-59. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The provisions of this division shall not apply on the premises of a duly licensed automobile repair or sales business or on the premises of a duly licensed automobile junking yard, provided that the person owning or possessing the vehicle on such premises receives a substantial portion of his annual income from the operation of such business. 
(b)  The provisions of this division shall not apply to vehicles stored in closed buildings. 
(Ord. No. 731, § 1, 7-24-89) 
Chapter 14 - HOUSING[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 14-1-14-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FAIR HOUSING 

Sec. 14-26. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein unless the context otherwise indicates: 
    Financial institution means any person regularly engaged in the business of lending money or guaranteeing loans on housing accommodations or real property. 
    Housing accommodation means any building or portion thereof, whether such building or portion is constructed or is to be constructed, which is used or intended for use as the residence or sleeping place of one (1) or more persons. The term "housing accommodation" shall not mean or include: 
(1)  The rental of a dwelling, or a portion thereof, containing accommodation for no more than two (2) families, one (1) of which is occupied by the owner or his family at the time of rental. 
(2)  The rental of less than four (4) rooms in a one-family dwelling to another person by the owner or occupant of such accommodation in which he or members of his family reside. 
(3)  The sale or rental of government sponsored housing intended specifically for older persons. 
    Owner means and includes the owners, lessee, sublessee, assignee, manager, agent or other person, firm or corporation, having the right to sell, rent or lease any housing accommodation or real property within the city limits. 
    Person means and includes one (1) or more individuals, partnerships, associations, organizations, corporations, legal representatives, trustees, trustees in bankruptcy or receivers. 
    Real estate broker means any person who, for a fee or other valuable consideration, sells, purchases, exchanges, rents, negotiates, offers or attempts to negotiate the sale, purchase, exchange or rental of housing accommodations or real property of another person. 
    Real estate salesman or agent means any person employed by a real estate broker to perform, or to assist in the performance of, any or all of the functions of a real estate broker. 
    Real property means and includes all real estate, leaseholds and any vacant land offered for sale or rent. 
    Unlawful discriminatory housing practice means any discrimination or segregation or separation against any person or group of persons because of race, sex, national origin or ancestry, religion, handicap or on account of the fact that a family may have children, and shall include only those types of unlawful practices and acts as set forth in section 14-28. 
(Ord. No. 628, § 1, 10-17-88; Ord. No. 1577, art. 1, 8-1-94; Ord. No. 2321, art. 1, 2-2-98) 
Sec. 14-27. - Policy statement. 
    The city council hereby declares it to be the public policy of the city to eliminate discrimination and safeguard the right of any person to sell, purchase, lease, rent, or obtain financing for real property without regard to race, color, sex, national origin or ancestry, religion, handicap and without regard to whether a family has children. It is further declared to be the public policy of the city that the design and construction of new multi-family dwellings with four (4) or more units must meet certain adaptability and accessibility requirements to be established by the city. This article shall be deemed an exercise of the police powers of the city for the protection of the public welfare, prosperity, health, and peace of the people of the city. 
(Ord. No. 628, § 1, 10-17-88; Ord. No. 1577, art. 1, 8-1-94; Ord. No. 2321, art. 2, 2-2-98) 
Sec. 14-28. - Unlawful practices. 
    It shall be an unlawful discriminatory housing practice: 
(1)  For the owner, real estate broker, real estate salesman, or employee or agent thereof: 
a.  To refuse to sell, rent, assign, lease or sublease, or offer for sale, rental, lease, assignment or sublease, or to refuse to negotiate for the sale, rental, lease, assignment or sublease of any real property or portion thereof which is in fact listed or available for sale, rent, lease or sublease to any person who has shown the financial ability to satisfy the terms and conditions of a sale, rental, assignment, lease or sublease of such property, or to otherwise deny or withhold any housing accommodations or real property or any part or portion hereof to or from any person because of the race, color, sex, religion, national origin or ancestry, or handicap of such person or because such person is the head of a household having children. 
b.  To discriminate against any person because of his race, color, sex, religion, national origin or ancestry, or handicap or because that person is the head of a family having children, in the terms, conditions or privileges of the sale, lease, rental, assignment or sublease of any housing accommodations or real property or part or portion thereof or in the furnishing of facilities or services in connection therewith. 
c.  To print, publish, circulate, issue, display, post or mail, or cause to be printed, published, circulated, issued, displayed, posted or mailed, any statement, advertisement, publication or sign, or use any form of application for the purchase, rental, lease, assignment or sublease of any housing accommodations or real property or part or portion thereof which expresses, directly or indirectly, any limitation, specification or discrimination as to race, color, sex, religion, national origin or ancestry, handicap or on account of the fact that such person is the head of a family having children, or any intent to make any such limitation, specification or discrimination. 
(2)  For any person, financial institution or loan institution to which application is made for financial assistance for the purchase, acquisition or construction of any housing accommodations or real property or part or portion thereof, or any agent or employee thereof: 
a.  To discriminate against any person because of the race, color, sex, religion, national origin or ancestry, handicap of such person or because such person is the head of a family having children, or of prospective occupants or tenants of such housing accommodations or real property or part or portion thereof in the granting, withholding, extending, modifying or renewing or in the fixing of the rates, terms, conditions, or provisions of any such financial assistance, or in the extension of services in connection therewith. 
b.  To use any form of application for such financial assistance or to make any record or inquiry in connection with applications for such financial assistance which expresses, directly or indirectly, any limitation, specification or discrimination as to race, sex, religion, national origin or ancestry, handicap or on account of the fact that such applicant is the head of a family having children, or any intent to make any such limitation, specification or discrimination. 
(3)  For any person, owner, real estate broker, real estate salesman or agent thereof: 
a.  To discriminate against any person because of the race, color, sex, religion, national origin or ancestry, handicap of such person or of prospective occupants or tenants of such housing accommodations or real property or part or portion thereof, or on account of the fact that such person is the head of a family having children, in the granting, withholding, extending, modifying or renewing, or in the fixing of the rates, terms, conditions or provisions of any such financial assistance or in the extension of services in connection therewith. 
b.  To use any form of application for such financial assistance or to make any record or inquiry in connection with applications for such financial assistance which expresses, directly or indirectly, any limitation, specification or discrimination as to race, color, sex, religion, national origin or ancestry, handicap or because of the fact that such person is the head of a family having children, or any intent to make any such limitation, specification or discrimination. 
(4)  For any person, owner, real estate broker, real estate salesman, or agent thereof: 
a.  To discriminate or to engage in economic or other reprisals against another person because such person complies with the provisions of this article or has opposed any practice forbidden under this article, or has filed a complaint, testified, or assisted in any proceedings under this article. 
b.  To aid, abet, incite, compel, coerce, cooperate or participate in the doing of any act declared to be a discriminatory practice under the provisions of this article, or to obstruct or prevent compliance with the provisions of this article, or to attempt directly or indirectly to commit any act declared by this article to be discriminatory practice. 
c.  To induce or attempt to induce the sale or listing for sale of any dwelling unit, commercial unit or real property or any part or portion thereof by representing that a change has occurred or will or may occur with respect to the racial, religious or ethnic composition of the block, neighborhood or area in which the property is located, or to induce or attempt to induce such sale by representing that the presence or anticipated presence of persons of any particular race, religion, sex, national origin or color in the area will or may result in: 
1.  The lowering of property values. 
2.  The change in the racial, religious or ethnic composition of the block, neighborhood or area in which the property is located. 
3.  An increase in criminal or antisocial behavior in the area. 
4.  A decline in the quality of the schools serving the area. 
(Ord. No. 628, § 1, 10-17-88; Ord. No. 1577, art. 1, 8-1-94; Ord. No. 2321, art. 3, 2-2-98) 
Sec. 14-29. - Exemptions. 
    Nothing in this article shall prohibit a religious organization, association or society, or any nonprofit institution or organization organized, supervised or controlled by or in conjunction with a religious organization, association or society, from limiting the sale, rental or occupancy of dwellings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose to persons of the same religion, or from giving preference to such persons. Nor shall anything in this article prohibit a private club not in fact open to the public, which as an incident to its primary purpose or purposes provides lodging which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose, from limiting the rental or occupancy of such lodging to its members or from giving preference to its members. 
(Ord. No. 628, § 1, 10-17-88; Ord. No. 1577, art. 1, 8-1-94) 
Sec. 14-30. - Administration. 
(a)  Any person claiming to be aggrieved of an unlawful discriminatory housing practice, hereinafter referred to as "complainant," may on his own behalf, or by his attorney, make, sign and file with the city clerk a complaint in writing, under oath, which shall state the name and address of the person alleged to have committed an unlawful discriminatory housing practice. Such complaint shall set forth the particulars thereof and contain such other information as may support the allegations contained therein. 
(b)  Any complaint filed under this article must be filed within thirty (30) days after the date of the alleged incident. 
(c)  In the event of a complaint being filed pursuant to this section, a true copy of such complaint shall forthwith be transmitted by certified United States mail, postage prepaid, addressed to the person complained against. 
(d)  The city clerk, upon receipt of a complaint filed pursuant to this article and in accordance with the requirements of this article, shall forthwith refer such complaint to the state commission on human rights for processing in accordance with Missouri Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 628, § 1, 10-17-88; Ord. No. 1577, art. 1, 8-1-94) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 14-31. - Penalties. 
    Upon a finding by the state commission on human rights that any person has violated any of the provisions of this article, that person shall be subject to the penalties and remedies set forth in Missouri Statutes as provided by an order of the state commission on human rights or a court of law, all pursuant to Missouri Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 628, § 1, 10-17-88; Ord. No. 1577, art. 1, 8-1-94) 
Chapter 15 - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Definitions. 
    Terms used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Architect means any person who plans or designs buildings or grounds for others, or who supervises and oversees the construction, alteration, repair or remodeling of the same. 
    Artist means any person skilled in any branch of the fine arts, such as music, painting or sculpture, who engages in or practices such art for a consideration. 
    Auctioneer means any person who shall sell or offer to sell any goods, wares or merchandise, or any real or personal property, or any interest therein, at public outcry to the highest bidder, for a fee or commission. 
    Auction store or company means any place, stand or store where goods, wares, merchandise or property of any kind are regularly or frequently sold or offered for sale at public outcry to the highest bidder. 
    Auto accessory dealer means any person who shall buy, manufacture or assemble and sell or offer for sale any tires or other fixtures, appliances or accessories to or for automobiles, trucks or trailers except persons, etc., who are licensed as merchants. 
    Automobile agency means any person who sells, trades or offers to sell or trade automobiles, trucks, trailers or buses which are not the property of such person, as the employee, agent or representative of a nonresident manufacturer, owner or dealer. 
    Automobile dealer means any person who shall buy, for the purpose of sale or trade, or who shall sell, trade or offer to sell or trade automobiles or motor vehicles. 
    Auto wrecking shop or garage means any shop, stand or place of business where automobiles or motor vehicles are dismantled, wrecked, remodeled, repaired, rebuilt for others for a consideration. 
    Auto yard means any yard, space or enclosure where motor vehicles are kept, stored or parked for a consideration. 
    Bakery means any shop, stand, store or place where bread, cakes, cookies, doughnuts, pies, pastries and/or similar products are manufactured, prepared, sold or offered for sale, except a person licensed to do business as a merchant who sells but does not manufacture such products. 
    Bank means any place of business or establishment where money and/or valuables are deposited, kept, issued, loaned and/or exchanged. 
    Barber means any person who for a consideration cuts or trims the hair or beard, or performs any of the other services commonly offered in barbershops, or offers to do so. 
    Barbershop means any shop, stand, or place where barbers ply their trade or profession. 
    Bathhouse means any building, room, structure or premises where for a fee or charge persons are invited and permitted to bathe, swim and/or dress for swimming or bathing. 
    Beauty parlor means any shop, room, stand or place where for a consideration service, substances, services or things designed or intended to improve or enhance the appearance are sold or dispensed. 
    Billposter means any person who shall tack, nail, paste or otherwise attach to billboards, fences, buildings or other structures, any bills, notices, posters, signs or other advertising material, except legal notices issued by or under the direction of a court. 
    Blacksmith shop means any shop, stand or place where horses are shod, and/or metal is worked or fashioned or metal objects are made, altered or repaired. 
    Bookbinder means any person who makes, binds or repairs books or pamphlets. 
    Bottling works means any place or establishment where soft drinks or other liquids are prepared and bottled. 
    Bowling alley means any room, stand or place equipped and used for bowling or playing the game of tenpins where an admission or fee is charged. 
    Brick contractor means any person who shall contract or undertake to build, erect, construct or repair any object, structure, walk or pavement with brick, or to lay or place brick, except his own labor. 
    Broker means any person who acts or offers to act as the agent or representative of others in matters of trade, commerce or navigation, and receives or charges a fee or commission for such a service. 
    Building contractor means any person who contracts or undertakes to erect, construct, raze, remodel or repair any building or structure for others except a person who contracts or undertakes thereby to furnish nothing except his own labor. 
    Bulk plant means any place of business handling petroleum products which have a tank or tanks for the purpose of storing petroleum products, which tank or tanks have or aggregate a capacity of twenty thousand (20,000) gallons or more and from which place of business petroleum products are transported either by the owner of such place of business or by any other person for the purpose of resale by any person whomsoever, either at wholesale or retail. 
    Butcher, retail means any person who shall kill, cut, prepare and/or sell or offer to sell any fresh meat in quantities less than one-quarter of a carcass. 
    Canvasser means any person who shall go from place to place or from person to person and solicit or accept orders for the sale of goods, wares or merchandise, or similarly solicits money, influence, signatures or information. 
    Carnival means any collection or group of stands, shows or entertainment devices commonly included within the term carnival or street fair. 
    Caterer means any adult person or entity engaged in the retail sale of food and service for use at a particular function, occasion or event at a particular location other than the caterer's premises. 
    Cement contractor means any person who contracts or undertakes to build, construct or repair any structures, objects or surfaces of cement or concrete except a person who undertakes to furnish nothing except his own labor. 
    Cigar or tobacco stand means any store, shop, stand or place where cigars, cigarettes and/or tobacco is sold, distributed or offered for sale. 
    Circus means any dog and pony show, wild animal show or variety show exhibited in a tent or tents. 
    Cleaning establishments means any shop, stand or place of business where clothing or other articles are washed, cleaned or renovated. 
    Collection agency means any person who for a fee or commission collects or attempts to collect notes, accounts or obligations for others. 
    Confectioner means any person who shall sell, deal in or offer for sale any candies, nuts, popcorn, chewing gum, fruits, ice cream, sweetmeats, cold drinks, light lunches or other confections, except a person duly licensed as a druggist or merchant. 
    Dance hall means any place where public dances or balls are held or conducted where an admission or charge for dancing is made. 
    Druggist or pharmacist means any person who compounds and sells or offers for sale any drugs or medicines, or any of the other articles or things commonly found in drugstores. 
    Dye works means any shop, store, stand or place where for a consideration, clothing or other articles or fabrics are dyed, colored or bleached. 
    Employment office or agency means any person or establishment which for a consideration seeks or offers to find employment or employees for others. 
    Express company agency, express company or common carrier means any office, depot or establishment where property or articles are accepted or received for shipment by express or from which such articles are delivered to the consignees. 
    Florist means any person who sells or offers for sale flowers or flowering or decorative plants. 
    Fortuneteller means any person who shall predict or purport to foretell future events or occurrences by whatever means or in whatever manner. 
    Foundry means any shop, stand, factory or place where metals are melted, poured, molded or fashioned for sale or for another for a fee or charge. 
    Gauger means any person who shall gauge or measure any articles or substances for others for a consideration. 
    Gift enterprise means any contest of skill, or any casting of lots in which one (1) or more winners are given gifts or prizes. 
    Grocer means any person who sells or offers for sale foods or food products other than a butcher. 
    Hairdresser means any person who does or offers to cut, trim, curl, dye, dress or arrange the hair of other persons for a consideration. 
    Hairdressing shop means any shop, stand or place where hairdressers ply their trade or profession. 
    Hawker means any person who goes from place to place selling or offering for sale by public outcry on the streets any goods or articles. 
    Health school or club means any place, stand or establishment where for a consideration instructions as to exercise and/or diet intended or supposed to protect and improve the health are given or offered. 
    Horse and cattle dealer means any person who buys, sells or deals in horses or cattle or other livestock. 
    Hospital means any institution or establishment where ill, injured or infirm persons are kept and treated, except such an institution owned and operated by municipal, religious or charitable organization not for profit. 
    Hotel means any place or establishment where rooms and meals are regularly offered to the public. 
    Huckster means any person who deals at retail in vegetables or provisions, particularly one who deals therein from a wagon or open stand. 
    Ice cream parlor means any store, shop or place where ice cream, ices, sherbets or soft drinks are sold or served for consumption on the premises. 
    Ice cream stand means any booth or stand not provided with chairs and tables, where ice cream or other products mentioned in the next preceding paragraph are sold or served. 
    Ice cream vendor means any person who sells or vends ice cream or similar products at or from an open stand or from a wagon moved about from place to place. 
    Ice dealer means any person who buys, sells or deals in ice. 
    Ice plant means any plant or factory which manufactures ice for sale or distribution. 
    Ice plant agency means any person who sells or offers to sell ice for and as the employee, agent or representative of a plant, firm or person located outside this city. 
    Inspector means any person who for a fee or commission examines, inspects and checks the quantity or quality of merchandise or substances. 
    Installment agency means any person who for or as the employee, agent or representative of another, sells or offers for sale, goods, wares or merchandise which are to be paid in installments or payments, or who so sells or offers to sell any goods, wares or merchandise by sample for future delivery. 
    Installment house means any store, shop or establishment which sells or deals in any goods, wares or merchandise in either of the manners described in the next preceding paragraph. 
    Insurance agent means any person who solicits or accepts applications for insurance, or writes, sells, delivers or offers to write, sell or deliver policies of insurance, or who collects or receives premiums or charges for insurance as the employee, agent or representative of an insurance company, and maintains a business office within the city. 
    Insurance company means any company, association, joint adventure, copartnership or corporation which issues, writes, guarantees, accepts or offers to write, issue, guarantee or accept policies of insurance or indemnity upon the lives, persons, property or property rights of others, and maintains a business office within the city. 
    Intelligence agency means any person who for a consideration offers or undertakes to investigate any matter or to assemble information for others. 
    Job printing plant means any plant, shop or establishment, which does or offers to do printing for others for a consideration. 
    Junk dealer means any person who buys and/or sells old metals, rags, bottles, bones or secondhand machinery or similar articles or substances. 
    Laundry means any person who washes or irons or offers to wash or iron clothing or fabrics for others, except such person who performs such service in his own or his customer's private residence and who operates not more than one (1) washing machine and two (2) hand irons in so doing. 
    Laundry agency means any person who collects or delivers clothes or fabrics from or to customers or collects therefor as the employee agent or representative of a nonresident laundry. 
    Loan agent means any person who solicits, accepts or receives applications from parties seeking loans, or assists in the closing of such loans or collects or receives payments on loans as the agent, employee or representative of a lender not resident within this city. 
    Loan company means any company or organization engaged in the business of lending money or which offers to lend money to others for a consideration either in the way of interest or commission. 
    Lumber dealer means any person who buys, sells or deals in lumber or wood products. 
    Lunch counter means any stand or place where sandwiches, lunches and/or drinks are sold and served and where tables and chairs are not provided for the customers. 
    Lunchstand or lunch wagon means any open stand, booth or place where sandwiches, lunches and/or drinks are sold other than regular meals, and where tables and chairs are not provided for the customers, except those which come within the definition of a "lunch counter" as above set forth. 
    Machine shop means any shop, stand or establishment maintaining or operating machines for making or repairing articles of wood or metal, tools or equipment for others for a consideration. 
    Manufacturing corporation means any corporation engaged in the conversion of raw materials into articles or substances for consumption or use. 
    Manufacturing institution means any person or organization of any sort organized for or engaged in manufacturing. 
    Masseur means any person who for a consideration does or offers to do massaging or rubbing upon others. 
    Mercantile agent means any person who makes a business of collecting information relating to the credit, character, responsibility or reputation of merchants, for the purpose of furnishing such information to others for a consideration. 
    Merchant delivery company means any person or organization which makes a business of delivering goods or packages for merchants. 
    Merchant, retail means any person who buys, sells or deals in any goods, wares or merchandise at any store, stand or place of business within this city. 
    Money broker means any person who exchanges, lends, procures or raises money to or for others for a consideration. 
    Money changer means any person who exchanges money for others for a fee or commission. 
    Monument agency means any person or organization which deals in or in any way aids or assists the dealing in monuments or markers as the employee, agent or representative of a nonresident dealer. 
    Monument dealer means any person who buys for sale, sells, manufactures or deals in monuments or markers. 
    Moving picture show means any show or exhibition, or a theater used for showing or exhibiting moving pictures where admission is charged. 
    Museum means any collection of natural, scientific or literary curiosities or works of art, or a building or room housing the same, except any museum permanently maintained and owned and conducted by a religious, educational, charitable or municipal corporation. 
    Newspaper office means any shop, plant, office or establishment where newspapers are regularly printed, prepared, sold or distributed. 
    Nursery stock agent means any person who sells or distributes or solicits or accepts orders for trees, shrubs, plants or other nursery products. 
    Oil station means any shop, stand or place of business where gasoline, oils and/or petroleum products are sold or distributed, either at wholesale or retail, except where such sale or distribution is purely an incidental part of the business of a duly licensed merchant. 
    Opera house means any building, hall or room where for an admission charge, operatic performances or other musical programs are presented or held. 
    Optician means any person who makes, buys and sells, or repairs optical instruments or who treats diseases or defects of the eyes or vision. 
    Ordinary means any person who draws wills or codicils thereto, or who assists in the administration of estates for others for a consideration except regularly licensed attorneys or administrators or executors duly appointed by a competent court. 
    Organ dealer means any person who buys, sells or deals in organs of any kind. 
    Painting contractor means any person who contracts or undertakes to do any painting for others except a person who in so doing undertakes to furnish nothing except his own labor. 
    Palmist means any person who represents that he is able to or who does read or interpret the lines and markings on a person's palm for a consideration. 
    Paperhanger contractor means any person who contracts or undertakes to hang or place wallpaper except such person who undertakes to furnish nothing except his own labor. 
    Patent right dealer means any person who buys, sells or deals in patents or rights therein, or rights to use or sell patented articles or substances. 
    Pawnbroker means any person who lends or offers to lend money upon the security of articles of personal property deposited with such lender, or who deals in the purchase of personal property on condition that the seller may repurchase the same at a stipulated price, or who displays the sign or insignia of pawnbrokers. 
    Peanut stand means any shop, stand, booth or place where peanuts are sold or dispensed except such shop holding a license as a merchant, lunch stand or counter, restaurant or confectioner. 
    Peddler means any person who sells or offers to sell at retail any goods, wares or merchandise except newspapers, Bibles or religious tracts by carrying the same for sale from place to place. 
    Photographer means any person who makes for sale or for a consideration, any photographs or pictures made by the motion of light. 
    Piano and organ agent means any person who acts as the employee, agent or representative within this city of a nonresident piano or organ dealer. 
    Piano dealer means any person who buys, sells or deals in pianos of any kind. 
    Picture show means any show, entertainment, display or exhibition of or by means of pictures of any sort. 
    Pistol or shooting gallery means any room, stand, booth or place where for a consideration persons are permitted to shoot with pistols or revolvers. 
    Plastering contractor means any person who contracts or undertakes to make, apply, patch or repair any plastering except such person who undertakes to furnish nothing but his own labor. 
    Plumbing contractor means any person who contracts or undertakes to install, remove, repair or maintain any pipes, traps, fixtures or appliances for the conveyance, disposal or use of water, gas or sewage, and who furnishes or supplies more than his own labor. 
    Pool hall means any place or establishment where pool tables, platforms or devices designed and used for playing the game of pool or pocket billiards. 
    Pool table means any table, platform or device designed and used for playing the game of pool or pocket billiards. 
    Popcorn stand means any shop, booth, stand or place where popcorn is sold or dispensed, except such establishment holding a license as a merchant, lunchstand, restaurant or confectionery. 
    Porter means any person who opens or closes doors or acts as doorkeeper or who carries or conveys luggage, parcels, etc., for others. 
    Poultry dealer means any person who buys, sells or deals in domestic fowl or the meat or eggs thereof. 
    Pressing establishment means any shop, stand or place where clothes or fabrics are pressed for others for a consideration. 
    Produce dealer means any person who buys, sells or deals in agricultural or farm products. 
    Public building, public grounds or public hall means any building or structure, tract or space, hall or room used by or for the public or public functions, for a consideration. 
    Ready-to-wear clothing agency means any person who solicits or accepts orders for, delivers, collects or receives money for ready-made clothing as the agent, employee or representative of a nonresident maker or owner. 
    Real estate agency means any company, association, joint venture, copartnership or corporation which sells, trades, rents, leases or manages, or offers to sell, trade, rent, lease or manage any real estate for others for a fee or commission, and maintains a business office within the city. 
    Restaurant means any inn, establishment, adult person or entity, other than a caterer while performing catering services, engaged in the retail sale of food prepared by the restaurant, or by using the restaurant's facilities, on or off the premises and sold for immediate consumption within or away from the premises. The term "restaurant," however, shall not include entities that are exempt from federal income tax while engaged in their exempt functions and activities, but shall include hospitals, nursing homes, and convalescent centers unless they are engaged in the preparation and delivery of food to their patients or residents. 
    Runner or solicitor means any person who solicits business or customers on the streets or from place to place, for steamboats, cars, stages, taxis, hotels, roominghouses, boardinghouses, bathhouses, masseurs, physicians, chiropractors, osteopaths, hospitals, sanitariums or health schools. 
    Sand plant means any establishment where sand and/or gravel is mined, pumped, dug or otherwise acquired for sale, or sold or offered for sale. 
    Sanitarium means any establishment where for a consideration persons are kept and treated for the prevention or alleviation of diseases of the mind or body. 
    Sewer contractor means any person who contracts or undertakes to build, install, extend, rebuild or repair any sewer or system of sewers or any plant or system for the disposal of sewage, except a person who undertakes to furnish nothing except his own labor. 
    Sewing machine agent means any person who buys, sells or deals in or offers to buy, sell or deal in sewing machines as the employee, agent or representative of a nonresident person or firm. 
    Shoe cobbler shop means any shop, stand or place where boots, shoes or other footwear are repaired, mended or rebuilt for others for a consideration. 
    Shoe shining parlor means any room, shop, stand or place which does or offers to shine, dye or polish shoes for others. 
    Show means any exhibition or entertainment to which admission is charged or a parade or procession advertising the same. 
    Sidewalk contractor means any person who contracts or undertakes to build, lay, install, remove or repair any sidewalk or foot pavement for others for a consideration, except such person who undertakes to furnish nothing except his own labor. 
    Skating rink means any place where persons are invited to skate, to which admission is charged. 
    Soft drink stand or vendor means any person who or place where soft drinks or nonalcoholic beverages are sold or served. 
    Stand means any shop, booth or place where business of any kind is transacted. 
    Steamfitter means any person not holding a plumber's license who installs, removes, repairs or offers to install, remove or repair any pipe, fixture or apparatus for the conveyance or use of steam. 
    Stockyard means any yard, pen or enclosure where livestock is held pending sale, slaughter or shipment, or is boarded, for compensation. 
    Stone contractor means any person who contracts or undertakes to cut, trim or lay rock or stone, or to build, construct or repair any structures or objects of rock or stone, except such person who undertakes to furnish nothing except his own labor. 
    Storage warehouse means any building, structure or place where for a consideration personal property of others of any sort or kind is stored or kept. 
    Street contractor means any person who contracts or undertakes to build, grade, curb, gutter, pave, repair or maintain any streets, alleys or highways. 
    Street exhibition means any show, entertainment or exhibition held or conducted upon a public street, alley, highway or other public place, to which admission is charged or at which goods or wares of any sort are offered for sale. 
    Subcontractor means any person who contracts or undertakes at the instance of another, any work which such other person has previously contracted or agreed to do or procure. 
    Tailor means any person who cuts, sews, makes or repairs clothing to fit the customer. 
    Tailor-made clothing agency means any person who as the employee, agent or representative of a nonresident tailor or manufacturer, forwards, solicits, or accepts orders, takes measurements, makes deliveries or collects money for clothing made to fit the measurements of the purchaser. 
    Tavern means any hotel, public house or similar place for the accommodation or entertainment of strangers. 
    Theatrical exhibition means any dramatic, operatic or similar exhibition such as is usually presented or seen in a theater. 
    Tinner means any person who works with tin or other sheet metal, or who builds, installs, makes, removes or repairs objects composed solely or chiefly of sheet metal. 
    Traveling store means any stock of goods, wares or merchandise offered for sale which is moved about from place to place within the city. 
    Undertaker or funeral director means any person who undertakes to conduct funerals or care for bodies of the dead. 
    Venereal hospital, private means any hospital, sanitarium or place where for a consideration persons suffering with venereal diseases are kept or treated, except such an institution or place owned and operated by a municipal, religious or charitable corporation. 
    Wholesale butcher means any person who kills for sale or who sells in quantities not less than one-quarter of a carcass, or who sells in any quantity to retailers thereof, any fresh meat or meat products. 
    Wholesale merchant means any person who sells or offers to sell any goods, wares or merchandise to retailers or to other persons for resale by such purchasers. 
    Wood dealer means any person who buys, sells or deals in wood or kindling. 
    The specification of meanings of this section shall not be exclusive and shall not be construed to exclude other matters not herein specified which are usually and ordinarily included within the various terms here defined. 
(Code 1967, § 16-3; Ord. No. 2379, art. 1, 7-6-98; Ord. No. 4510, art. 1, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 15-2. - License for certain occupations, businesses and trades-Required; application. 
(a)  Required. No person shall engage in any of the occupations, businesses or trades, nor do or operate any of the things in this section mentioned, without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(b)  Application. Application for the license shall be made to the city clerk who shall issue the same upon payment of the license tax. 
(Code 1967, § 16-2) 
Sec. 15-3. - Same-License tax schedule; duration. 
(a)  There is hereby levied a forty dollar ($40.00) license tax for the privilege of engaging in the following vocations, occupations or callings, or conducting or operating or maintaining the following businesses or occupations within the city which license tax shall be for one (1) year, commencing on January 1 of each year, unless a different period of time is stated. All renewals of licenses shall be made on January 1 of each year.

(2)  Artist;

(6)  Bank, loan company or loan agent;

(2)  Peddler; or 
(3)  Traveling or transient store. 
(Code 1967, § 16-3; Ord. No. 2379, art. 1, 7-6-98; Ord. No. 4510, art. 2, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 15-4. - Telephone companies; license tax levied; to be in lieu of other occupational taxes. 
(a)  Levied; method of payment. Every person engaged in the business of supplying telephone service for compensation within the city shall pay to the city as a license tax a sum equal to five (5) percent of all gross receipts derived from the business of supplying telephone service within the city, up to twenty-seven thousand five hundred dollars ($27,500.00) per year per licensee. The tax imposed by this section shall be computed and paid semi-annually on January 20 and July 20 each year for the preceding full six-month period, each such payment not to exceed thirteen thousand seven hundred fifty dollars ($13,750.00). The respective companies shall file with the city clerk on or before each such date a verified statement showing the gross taxable revenue and accompanying tax payment of each such company applicable to the preceding six-month period ending June 30 and December 31 of each year. 
(b)  Telephone service. For purposes of the tax imposed in subsection (a), a "business of supplying telephone service" shall mean any business that provides telephone service within the city, regardless of the technology or means of transmission, including but not limited to wireless, wired, local exchange and internet-based transmission, to the full extent permitted by applicable law. 
(c)  Tax in lieu of other occupational taxes. This tax shall be in lieu of any other occupational tax required of any person engaged in the business of supplying telephone service for compensation within this city, but shall not exempt any such person from the payment to the city of any tax which the city may levy upon the real or personal property belonging to any such person, or from any tax levied upon anything other than telephone service. 
(d)  Authority of city clerk to inspect, audit records. The city clerk shall have the right, during regular business hours, to inspect and audit the books and records of any person subject to the license tax imposed by this section to confirm the correctness of the return and amount of tax required to be paid pursuant this section. 
(Code 1967, § 16-4; Ord. No. 3751, art. 1, 11-6-06) 
Sec. 15-5. - Issuance of licenses prohibited until delinquent taxes and fees are paid; all licenses required; duties of city clerk. 
(a)  Except as may be otherwise required by law or expressly waived by the city manager: 
(1)  No merchant's license, wholesaler's license, manufacturer's license, occupation license, or any other license shall be issued by the city or by any department thereof to any applicant, until all state or local sales taxes, personal property taxes, merchant's license taxes, ad valorem taxes, wholesaler's license taxes, manufacturer's license taxes, occupation license taxes, sewer service charges, water service charges, solid waste fees, license or permit fees, or any other city taxes, fees or charges, including special tax bills and assessments of the applicant therefor, due and payable or payable during any previous calendar year, shall first have been paid in full, together with any interest and penalties. 
(2)  No merchant's license, wholesaler's license, manufacturer's license, occupation license, or any other license shall be issued by the city or by any department thereof to any applicant, until such person has obtained all other licenses required by the Code of Ordinances of the City of Cape Girardeau, Missouri, and paid all fees required therefor, together with any interest and penalties. 
(3)  No merchant's license, wholesaler's license, manufacturer's license, occupation license, or any other license shall be issued by the city or by any department thereof to any applicant unless the building and premises for which the license is sought complies with all applicable provisions of the zoning ordinance, subdivision regulations, development code and building codes of the city, and conforms to all applicable health and sanitation requirements of the city. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, a tax or fee due and in arrears by the applicant shall include any such amount owed by the applicant, whether jointly or severally or in joint tenancy with any other person or entity. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Applicant. An individual or a corporation, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, organization or entity of any kind, including any shareholder, owner, officer, partner, joint venturer or member of such entity or any related person or entity, or any other person holding an ownership interest in such entity requesting any city permit, license, franchise or other approval. 
(2)  City or local. City of Cape Girardeau, Missouri. 
(3)  Related person or entity. 
a.  A firm, partnership, joint venture, association, organization or entity of any kind in which the applicant holds any stock, title, or other ownership interest of at least twenty (20) percent. 
b.  A firm, partnership, joint venture, association, organization, or entity of any kind which holds any stock, title, or other ownership interest in the applicant of at least twenty (20) percent. 
c.  An individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, organization or entity of any kind, whose affairs the applicant has the legal or practical ability to direct, either directly or indirectly, whether by contractual agreement, majority ownership interest, any lessor ownership interest, familial relationship or any other manner. 
(4)  State. State of Missouri. 
(d)  When the city reasonably believes that the applicant has any control or ownership interest in an entity subject to this section, the applicant shall have the burden to document ownership of less than twenty (20) percent if the applicant seeks city action otherwise precluded by this section. 
(e)  It shall be the duty of the city clerk to establish an effective system of cross-checking to determine whether any applicant for a license has obtained all other licenses required by this Code, and owes any personal property tax, merchant's license tax, ad valorem tax, wholesaler's tax, manufacturer's license tax, occupation license tax, sewer service charges, water service charges, solid waste fees, license or permit fees or any other city taxes, fees or charges including special tax bills and assessments and any interest and penalties thereon. 
(Code 1967, § 16-5; Ord. No. 1995, § 2, 7-15-96; Ord. No. 2379, art. 2, 7-6-98; Ord. No. 4118, art. 2, 5-3-10; Ord. No. 4281, art. 2, 12-5-11; Ord. No. 4924, art. 1, 12-5-16) 
Cross reference- Deputy city clerks, § 2-55. 
Sec. 15-6. - Failure to do business authorized; tax refund prohibited. 
    If the person receiving a license fails to do the business authorized by the license, no amount of the tax shall be refunded. 
(Code 1967, § 16-6) 
Sec. 15-7. - Transfer prohibited. 
    No license granted under this chapter shall be transferred or assigned. 
(Code 1967, § 16-7) 
Sec. 15-8. - Issuance. 
    Duty of city clerk. It shall be the duty of the city clerk to issue a license to any person who complies with the conditions specified for the issuance of such license. ;hm0; (Ord. No. 4606, art. 1, 7-21-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4606, art. 1, adopted July 21, 2014, repealed the former § 15-8, and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 15-8 pertained to issuance, form and contents, and derived from Code 1967, § 16-8. 
Sec. 15-9. - Notice of expiration date; failure to renew. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk, at least fifteen (15) days before the expiration of any license issued under this chapter, to notify the licensee by mail, or in person, of the date of expiration of such license. If such licensee fails to renew the same by taking out a new license, the city clerk shall report such fact to the city attorney and chief of police. Any failure of the city clerk to so notify such person shall not excuse any licensee for failure to renew such license. 
(Code 1967, § 16-9) 
Sec. 15-10. - Disposition of taxes. 
    All license taxes collected under this chapter shall be paid into the general revenue fund. 
(Code 1967, § 16-10) 
Sec. 15-11. - Limitations on use of licenses. 
    No license issued under this chapter, except under Article III of this chapter, shall authorize or permit any licensee to conduct more than one (1) business under such license, and no license issued under this chapter shall authorize any person to conduct the business or do the things therein mentioned at more than one (1) place or establishment within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 16-11) 
Sec. 15-12. - Unlawful to operate, assist, etc., an unlicensed business; rebuttable presumption. 
(a)  No person shall engage in, operate, carry on, conduct or participate in doing any business in this city for which a license is required by this chapter or assist directly or indirectly in doing such business or any part of the same, in any manner, either as owner or proprietor or as an officer of any corporation, or as manager, agent, superintendent, servant or employee, unless a license for carrying on such business shall have been issued and shall be in force. 
(b)  There shall be a rebuttable presumption that the licensee and such business is operating as an unlicensed business in violation of this chapter, if the licensee fails to properly renew any license issued under the terms of this chapter, or to notify the city clerk in writing of the closure of the business and the timely filing of all statements and payments required by section 15-88, et seq., of the City Code. 
(Code 1967, § 16-12; Ord. No. 4395, art. 1, 12-3-12) 
Sec. 15-13. - Suspension or revocation when licensee convicted of misdemeanor. 
    When any person licensed under any provision of this chapter is convicted of a misdemeanor for violating any of the ordinances of this city, which violation shall have occurred in the conduct or operation of the business, vocation, occupation or calling of such person, the license of such person may be suspended or revoked by the city manager upon satisfactory proof of such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 4756, art. 2, 9-1-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4756, art. 2, adopted Sept. 1, 2015, repealed the former § 15-13, and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 15-13 pertained to revocation when licensee convicted of misdemeanor and derived from Code 1967, § 16-13. 
Sec. 15-14. - When taxes delinquent; penalty. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law, the penalty provisions of RSMo § 144.250 relating to delinquent sales taxes shall apply to delinquent taxes due as a result of a license tax imposed by the terms of the chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 16-14; Ord. No. 4396, art. 1, 12-3-12; Ord. No. 4642, art. 1, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 15-15. - Peddlers, solicitors, hawkers, etc., selling goods on private premises; restrictions. 
    No solicitor, peddler, hawker, itinerant merchant or transient vendor or other person shall go in and upon any private residence for the purpose of selling, or soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise, services or subscriptions without having been requested or invited to do so by the owner or occupant of the private residence. 
(Code 1967, § 16-15) 
Sec. 15-16. - Peddlers, merchants or other persons prohibited from streets, intersections, sidewalks. 
    No person, peddler, huckster, hawker, solicitor, vendor, or merchant shall conduct activity in the public streets, rights-of-way, intersections, medians or sidewalks, in such a manner where his operations impedes or interferes with pedestrians or vehicle traffic. This section shall not apply to the commercial selling of newspapers on sidewalks. 
(Ord. No. 4922, art. 2, 12-5-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4922, art. 2, adopted Dec. 5, 2016, repealed the former § 15-16 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 15-16 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1967, § 16-16; Ord. No. 2888, art. 1, adopted May 21, 2001; Ord. No. 2930, art. 1, adopted Sep. 4, 2001; Ord. No. 3669, art. 1, adopted June 5, 2006; and Ord. No. 3932, art. 1, adopted June 16, 2008. 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, ch. 24; stopping, standing and parking, § 26-246 et seq.; display of merchandise, etc., on public property, § 24-5. 
Sec. 15-17. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2179, art. 1, adopted June 16, 1997, repealed § 15-17, which pertained to barbers, beauty shops, hours of operating prescribed. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 15-18. - Auto wrecking and junkyards; requirements for establishing and operating. 
    No auto wrecking yard or junkyard shall be established, maintained or operated within view of any public street in the city unless such auto wrecking yard or junkyard is screened from view by tight board or other screen fence in good repair, not less than ten (10) feet high, or of sufficient height to screen the wrecked or disabled automobiles, or junk, kept therein from the view of persons using the public streets on foot or in vehicles in the ordinary manner. 
(Code 1967, § 16-18) 
Cross reference- Traffic, ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Junkyards, RSMo, § 226.650 et seq. 
Secs. 15-19-15-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MERCHANTS' AND MANUFACTURERS' AD VALOREM TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Merchants' and manufacturers' licenses and taxes, RSMo, § 150.010 et seq. 

Sec. 15-46. - Levy on merchants; method of computation. 
    All merchants shall pay, in addition to the license tax provided in this chapter, an ad valorem tax equal to that which is levied upon real estate, upon the highest amount of all goods, wares and merchandise which they have in their possession and under their control, whether owned by them or consigned to them for sale, at any time between the first Monday in March and the first Monday in June of each year. No commission merchant is required to pay an ad valorem tax on any manufactured article, the growth or produce of this or any other state, which may have been consigned to him for sale, and in which he has no ownership or interest other than a commission for making such sale. 
(Code 1967, § 16-28) 
Sec. 15-47. - Bond. 
    Any merchant who is not required to furnish the bond specified in section 15-84 shall, before being issued any license, in addition to paying the license tax, execute a bond to the city with two (2) or more good and sufficient sureties or a recognized corporate surety, conditioned that he will, on or before the first day of November next following, pay to the city clerk the proper ad valorem tax due to the city, which bond shall be approved by the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 16-29) 
Sec. 15-48. - Statement of inventory; verification. 
(a)  Required. Every merchant, on the first Monday in June of each year, shall furnish to the city assessor, a sworn statement of the greatest amount of goods, wares and merchandise which he may have had on hand at any one (1) time between the first Monday in March and the first Monday in June next preceding. The statement shall include goods, wares and merchandise owned by such merchant or consigned to him for sale by other parties. 
(b)  Statement to be verified. Such statement shall be signed and verified by such merchant or by some member of the firm, copartnership or other organization, before some officer authorized by law to administer oaths. 
(Code 1967, § 16-30) 
Sec. 15-49. - Levy on manufacturers; method of computation. 
    All manufacturers shall pay an ad valorem tax equal to that which is levied upon real estate, upon the greatest aggregate amount of all raw materials and finished product which they may have had on hand in any one (1) day, between the first Monday in March and the first Monday in June of each year. This requirement does not apply to manufacturers whose raw material, finished products, tools, machinery and appliances aggregate less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) in value. 
(Code 1967, § 16-31) 
Sec. 15-50. - Manufacturer to execute bond. 
    Any manufacturer shall, before being issued a license or commencing business as such manufacturer, execute a bond to the city, with two (2) or more good and sufficient sureties or a recognized corporate surety, conditioned that he will, on or before the first day of November next following, pay to the city clerk the proper ad valorem tax due to the city, which bond shall be approved by the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 16-32) 
Sec. 15-51. - Statement of raw materials, products; verification. 
(a)  Required. Every manufacturer doing business within the city, on the first Monday in June of each year, shall file with the city assessor a sworn statement of the greatest aggregate amount of raw material and finished products which he may have had on hand between the first Monday in March and the first Monday in June next preceding on any one (1) day between such times, and a sworn statement of the tools, machinery and appliances used in conducting his business or owned by him on the first day of June each year. 
(b)  Statement to be verified. Such statement shall be signed and verified by such manufacturer or by some member of the firm, copartnership or other organization, before some officer authorized by law to administer oaths. 
(Code 1967, § 16-33) 
Sec. 15-52. - City assessor to enter statements in tax book; form and contents. 
    It shall be the duty of the city assessor to enter such statements as required in sections 15-48 and 15-51 in a book prepared for that purpose, at the expense of the city, suitably ruled with columns for the name of the merchant or manufacturer, the amount of his statement to the assessor, the valuation of such statement, as equalized by the county board of equalization, and such other columns as may be found useful or convenient in practice. The book shall be verified by the affidavit of the city assessor annexed thereto, in the following form, to wit: 
"___________, being duly sworn, makes oath and says that he has made diligent efforts to secure sworn statements from all merchants and manufacturers doing business in the City of Cape Girardeau; that so far as he has been able to secure such statements, they are correctly set forth in the foregoing book." 
(Code 1967, § 16-34) 
Sec. 15-53. - Tax levy based on county valuations. 
    After the county board of equalization has completed the equalization of the statement as required in sections 15-48 and 15-51, the valuation as fixed by the board of equalization on the county assessor's merchants' and manufacturers' tax book shall be entered by the city assessor on the city merchants' and manufacturers' tax book in red ink, and returned to the city council. The city council shall levy taxes on the valuations as fixed by the county board of equalization at the same rate as assessed for the time on real estate, and the city clerk shall extend on such books all proper taxes at such rate; and he shall, on or before the first day of October make out the tax book. The sum of the valuation of the statements as equalized by the county board of equalization shall be included in and made a part of the total valuation of property taxable for city purposes. 
(Code 1967, § 16-35) 
Sec. 15-54. - Forfeiture of bond; grounds. 
(a)  Failure to file statement, pay tax. Every merchant or manufacturer to whom a license has been issued under this article who fails to file his statement at the time and in the manner required, or who has filed a correct statement and failed to pay the amount of tax owing to the city clerk, shall be deemed to have forfeited the bond given by him, and judgment shall be rendered for the plaintiff city in damages for double the amount of such tax and cost. 
(b)  False statement. Every merchant or manufacturer who files a false statement shall be deemed to have forfeited the bond given by him and judgment shall be rendered for the plaintiff city in damages for three (3) times the amount of tax found to be due for the year, and costs. 
(Code 1967, § 16-36) 
Sec. 15-55. - City clerk to institute suit on bond upon forfeiture. 
    Upon the forfeiture of any bond as provided herein, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to institute suit without delay upon the bond, against the principal and sureties jointly or severally, as may be deemed advisable. 
(Code 1967, § 16-37) 
Sec. 15-56. - Statement of merchant, manufacturer to be used as evidence in suit upon bonds. 
    In all suits upon bonds a certified copy of the statement required to be filed in the office of the city clerk, under his seal of office, shall be evidence of the amount of taxes due from such merchant or manufacturer so filing the same; but the city may show by competent testimony that such statement does not contain the full amount of taxable property required to be returned. When no statement has been filed, he may show by such testimony the amount of taxable property that should have been returned. 
(Code 1967, § 16-38) 
Sec. 15-57. - Penalty for knowingly filing false statement. 
    Any merchant or manufacturer who knowingly files a false statement under this article shall, in addition to forfeiting his bond as provided for in section 15-54, upon conviction, forfeit his license and be punished by a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for a period not exceeding three (3) months. 
(Code 1967, § 16-39) 
Sec. 15-58. - License; duration; restrictions. 
    No license granted under this chapter shall authorize any merchant or manufacturer to engage in his business at more than one (1) place within the city nor for a longer period than twelve (12) months. 
(Code 1967, § 16-40) 
Sec. 15-59. - Businesses commencing during year; requirements; computation of tax. 
(a)  Bond required. When any merchant or manufacturer commences his business in this city after the first Monday in June in any year, he shall execute a bond, conditioned that he will, on the first day of November next succeeding, furnish to the city assessor a statement verified as herein required, of the largest amount of goods, wares or merchandise, or raw materials and finished products, tools, machinery and appliances, which he had on hand or subject to his control, whether owned by him or consigned to him for sale, on the first day of any month, between the time when he commenced business and the first day of November next succeeding. 
(b)  Computation of tax. He shall pay the same rate of tax as other merchants and manufacturers prorated from the day when he commenced business to the first Monday in June next succeeding. 
(Code 1967, § 16-41) 
Secs. 15-60-15-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GROSS SALES LICENSE TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- City Sales Tax Act, RSMo, § 94.500 et seq. 
Annotation- In proceeding by automobile dealer to annul provisions of Ord. No. 752, enacted September 11, 1926, imposing a tax determined by the annual gross receipts for previous year, court held ordinance unconstitutional where different measures for the tax were imposed upon automobile dealers who had not been engaged in such business during previous calendar year and upon automobile dealers who had been engaged in such business during preceding calendar year. Cape Girardeau v. Groves Motor Co., 346, Mo. 762, 142 S.W. 2d 1040 (1930). 

Sec. 15-81. - Gross sales defined. 
    For the purposes of this article, the term "gross sales" shall mean the gross receipts of the business, occupation or calling for which the license was issued, either through the sale of merchandise or through the sale of services or derived through transactions of the licensee, whether such sales, services or transactions are for cash or on credit. 
(Code 1967, § 16-50) 
Sec. 15-82. - Levied; license required. 
    There is hereby levied a license tax upon the privilege of engaging within the city in any of the following named occupations or businesses, or doing or operating any of the following named things: auto accessories dealer, automobile agency, automobile dealer, bakery, retail butcher, cigar or tobacco stand, cleaning establishment, confectioner, druggist, dye works, florist, grocer, hotel, ice cream parlor, ice cream stand, ice cream vendor, ice dealer, ice plant, ice plant agency, installment house, installment agency, laundry, laundry agency, lumber dealer, lunch counter, lunchstand, lunch wagon, retail merchant of any kind, monument dealer, monument agency, moving picture show, poultry dealer, pressing establishment, produce dealer, ready-to-wear clothing agency, restaurant, soft drink stand or vendor, tailor-made clothing agency, tavern, retail oil station. No person shall engage in any of the occupations or conduct any of the businesses or do or operate any of the things mentioned in this section without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 16-51) 
Sec. 15-83. - Application for license. 
    Every person engaging in any business enumerated in the preceding section shall make application to the city clerk for a license. 
(Code 1967, § 16-52) 
Sec. 15-84. - Licensee required to give bond; city clerk to approve. 
    Upon making such application for a license, the applicant shall deliver to the city clerk the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) and a bond, signed by two (2) good and sufficient sureties who shall be residents of the city. The bond shall be approved by the city clerk and shall be conditioned upon the payment of the license tax. 
(Code 1967, § 16-53) 
Cross reference- Deputy city clerks, § 2-55. 
Sec. 15-85. - Form and content of bond. 
    The bond to be given by the applicant as required in the preceding section shall be in substantially the following form: 
     "WHEREAS, the Code of Ordinances of the City of Cape Girardeau provide for the execution and delivery of a bond to the City Clerk. 
     "NOW, THEREFORE, KNOW ALL MEN BY THESE PRESENTS: 
MERCHANT'S LICENSE BOND 
     "WHEREAS, ___________ has made application to the City of Cape Girardeau, Missouri, for a license for the privilege of engaging in the business ___________ in the City of Cape Girardeau for a period of one year, beginning on the _____ day of _______, 19___, pursuant to the provisions of the Code of Ordinances of Cape Girardeau. 
     "That we, ___________, as principal, and ___________ and ___________, as sureties, are held and firmly bound unto the City of Cape Girardeau, Missouri, for the payment, at the close of the year commencing the _____ day of _______, 19___, of all license taxes that may be due the City of Cape Girardeau, Missouri, from the principal of this bond for the year commencing the _____ day of _______, 19___, pursuant to and in accordance with the provisions of the Code of Ordinances of Cape Girardeau; and in default of such payment, to pay all judgments, damages and costs which may be adjudged against us. 
     "Given under our hands this _____ day of _______ 19___. 
_____
Principal _____
Surety _____
Surety  
     "Approved this _____ day of _______, 19___. 
_____
City Clerk"  
(Code 1967, § 16-54) 
Sec. 15-86. - Forfeiture of bond for failure to pay tax. 
    Every licensee who fails to pay his license tax shall be deemed to have forfeited the bond given, and upon the forfeiture of any bond, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to notify the city attorney who shall without delay institute suit upon the bond in the name of the city against the principal and sureties thereon. 
(Code 1967, § 16-55) 
Sec. 15-87. - Issuance of license; duration. 
    Upon receipt of the ten dollars ($10.00) and approval of the bond, the city clerk shall issue a license to the applicant granting the applicant the privilege of engaging in the business specified for a period of one (1) year, commencing on January 1 of each year. Current licenses expiring after January 1, 1999, shall be re-issued on January 1, 1999, for a period of one (1) year, and credit shall be given for the unused portion of the current license fee. Current licenses expiring after the effective date of this ordinance, but before January 1, 1999, shall be renewed only from their anniversary date to December 31, 1998. Thereafter, all renewals of licenses shall be made on January 1 of each year. Persons securing licenses after January 1 of any year shall pay for such portion of the license year remaining at the time such license is issued. 
(Code 1967, § 16-56; Ord. No. 2379, art. 3, 7-6-98) 
Sec. 15-88. - Licensees to furnish annual statement of gross receipts to city clerk. 
    Within five (5) days after the close of the year for which a license is issued, the licensee shall file with the city clerk in a manner and form to be prescribed by the clerk, and upon blanks furnished by him, a statement showing the amount of gross receipts for sales, services and transactions by such licensee during the year for which the license was issued. Such statement shall be verified by the affidavit of the licensee or his officer or agent. 
(Code 1967, § 16-57) 
Sec. 15-89. - Tax schedule. 
    At the close of the year for which the license is issued, the licensee shall pay for the license as follows: 
(1)  Gross sales less than $10,000.00. Where the annual gross sales of such licensee derived from his business, occupation or calling have amounted to less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) during the year for which the license was issued, the sum of ten dollars ($10.00). 
(2)  Gross sales more than $10,000.00. Where the annual gross sales of such licensee derived from his business, occupation or calling have amounted to more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) during the year for which the license was issued, the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) for the first ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) and one dollar ($1.00) for each one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or fractional part thereof in excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(3)  Licensee to receive $10.00 credit. The licensee shall receive as a credit on the license tax the ten dollars ($10.00) delivered to the city clerk at the time the license was issued. 
(Code 1967, § 16-58) 
Sec. 15-90. - Determination of daily gross sales. 
    The amount of the daily gross sales for the license year shall be fixed on the amount filed and sworn to by the licensee, or on the amount determined by the city clerk or his agent from the inspection and audit of the licensee's records and books, whichever is the greater. 
(Code 1967, § 16-59) 
Sec. 15-91. - Computation of gross sales when payments to licensee in merchandise. 
    For the purposes of this article, the value of any goods, wares and merchandise accepted by any licensee as part of the purchase price of goods, wares and merchandise sold or transferred by such licensee shall not be considered in determining gross sales, but the amount realized from the sale by the licensee of such goods, wares and merchandise so accepted shall be included in the gross sales of the year such goods, wares and merchandise are sold. This section applies to the sale by the licensee of any article accepted by such licensee for partial payment of the purchase price. The value of any article so accepted shall be the allowance or credit given the person offering such article to the licensee as a partial payment. 
(Code 1967, § 16-60) 
Sec. 15-92. - Computation of gross sales for business terminated during year. 
    If any licensee does not remain in business for the full year, the license tax shall be figured on the gross sales for the period such licensee remained in business on the basis provided for in this article. 
(Code 1967, § 16-61) 
Sec. 15-93. - City clerk authorized to inspect licensee's records, books. 
    All persons obtaining a license as herein provided shall at any time during regular business hours permit the city clerk or his agent to make an inspection and audit of the records and books of such licensee for the purpose of determining the correctness of the affidavit filed by such licensee. The information and data obtained from such inspection and audit shall not be disclosed by the city clerk or his agent; but this section shall not prohibit the city clerk or his agent from giving evidence in court in any proceeding brought to collect any license tax provided for in this section or to punish any licensee for the making of a false or fraudulent affidavit. 
(Code 1967, § 16-62) 
Secs. 15-94-15-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS SALES TAX 

Sec. 15-116. - Imposition; rules, regulations. 
    There is hereby imposed upon all sellers a tax for the privilege of engaging in the business of selling taxable personal property or rendering taxable services at retail to the extent and in the manner provided in RSMo 144.010-144.510, and the rules and regulations of the director of revenue issued pursuant thereto at the rate of one-fourth of one (1) percent on all retail sales made in the city which are subject to taxation under the provisions of RSMo 144.010-144.510. This tax is imposed pursuant to RSMo 94.577 and to the extent provided in RSMo 144.010-144.510 and the rules and regulations of the director of revenue issued pursuant thereto. 
(Ord. No. 615, § 1, 9-19-88) 
Sec. 15-117. - Purpose. 
    The tax imposed by this article is for the limited purpose of funding capital improvements for flood control, drainage improvement and storm- water control projects and may include the retirement of debt under previously authorized bonded indebtedness for such limited purposes. This tax shall be in addition to any and all other sales taxes allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. 615, § 1, 9-19-88) 
Sec. 15-118. - Trust fund. 
    There is hereby established a city capital improvements trust fund. All moneys received by the city from the capital improvements sales tax imposed by this article shall be deposited by the finance director to the credit of this fund and used in accordance with state statute. 
(Ord. No. 615, § 1, 9-19-88) 
Sec. 15-119. - When effective, duration. 
    The tax authorized by this article shall become effective on the first day of January, 1990 and such tax shall continue for a period of ten (10) years from its date of inception and thereafter shall automatically terminate unless extended or renewed in accordance with law. 
(Ord. No. 615, § 1, 9-19-88) 
Sec. 15-120. - Condition precedent; use of proceeds.
