All other activities and uses are specifically prohibited except those which are specifically approved in writing by the park superintendent. 
(Code 1967, § 20-6) 
Sec. 18-7. - Regulation of certain activities. 
(a)  No person in a city park shall: 
(1)  Removal of natural resources. Dig, or remove any beach sand, whether submerged or not, or any soil, rock, stones, trees, shrubs or plants, downtimber or other wood or materials, or make any excavation by tool, equipment, blasting, or other means or agency. 
(2)  Climbing trees, etc. Climb any tree or walk, stand, or sit upon any other property not designated or customarily used for such purposes. 
(3)  Use of receptacles. Deposit in receptacles in the city parks garbage, rubbish, or trash when such garbage, rubbish or trash is brought from a household or other place away from the city park. Receptacles provided by the city in the city parks are for those who are utilizing the parks and the utilization of such receptacles by individuals for the depositing of garbage, rubbish, or trash resulting from uses away from the city parks is prohibited. 
(4)  State motor vehicle laws apply. Fail to comply with all applicable provisions of the state motor vehicle traffic laws in regard to equipment and operation of vehicles together with such regulations as are contained in this and other ordinances. 
(5)  Enforcement of traffic regulations. Fail to obey all traffic officers and park employees, such persons being hereby authorized and instructed to direct traffic whenever and wherever needed in the parks and on the highways, streets or roads immediately adjacent thereto in accordance with the provisions of these regulations and such supplementary regulations as may be issued subsequently by the park superintendent or the police department. 
(6)  Obey traffic signs. Fail to observe carefully all traffic signs indicating speed, direction, caution, stopping, or parking, and all others posted for proper control and to safeguard life and property. 
(7)  Closed areas. Enter an area posted as "Closed to the Public," nor shall any person use, or abet the use of any area in violation of posted notices. 
(8)  Going onto ice. Go onto the ice on any of the waters except such areas as are designated skating fields, and provided a safety signal is displayed. 
(9)  Loitering and boisterousness. Sleep or protractedly lounge on the seats, or benches, or other areas, or engage in loud, boisterous, threatening, abusive, insulting or indecent language, or engage in any disorderly conduct or behavior tending to a breach of the public peace or to interfere with the use of the park by other citizens. The park superintendent or police officers shall have the authority to regulate the activities of individuals who are using the parks in the manner described. Visitors shall comply with directions given to achieve this end. 
(10)  Propelled objects. Take part in or abet the playing of any games involving thrown or otherwise propelled objects such as balls, stones, arrows, javelin or model airplanes when the playing of such is dangerous to those who are using the parks. 
(b)  The park superintendent or police officers shall have the authority to regulate the activities of individuals using the parks and all recreation trails when necessary to prevent congestion and to secure the maximum use for the comfort, safety and convenience of all. Visitors shall comply with directions given to achieve this end. 
(Code 1967, § 20-7; Ord. No. 2516, art. 1, 4-19-99) 
Secs. 18-8, 18-9. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1191, adopted June 15, 1992, repealed § 18-8 and § 18-9 in their entirety. Former § 18-8 was concerned with arena building fees and grandstand fees, and derived from § 20-9 of the Code of 1967. Former § 18-9, recreation program fees, derived from § 20-11 of the Code of 1967. 
Secs. 18-10-18-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARK AND RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; removal of members of boards and commissions, § 2-1. 

Sec. 18-26. - Created; membership. 
    There is hereby created a board consisting of eleven (11) citizens of the city, and one (1) ex officio member to be determined as set out in section 18-27(c), which shall be known and designated as the Cape Girardeau Park and Recreation Advisory Board. 
(Code 1967, § 20-15; Ord. No. 1850, art. 1, 1-8-96) 
Sec. 18-27. - Membership; terms; ex officio member. 
(a)  The city council shall appoint by formal motion and majority action eleven (11) members of the park and recreation advisory board. Except as otherwise provided in section 2-98, members of the park and recreation advisory board shall serve for terms of three (3) years, beginning on the thirtieth day of October. All members' terms shall be staggered so that four (4) members' terms shall expire each year, but every third year only three (3) members' terms shall expire. 
(b)  The mayor or a councilman designated by the mayor shall serve as an ex officio member of the park and recreation advisory board and shall maintain liaison with the city council and the city manager, but shall not have a vote in the decision of the board. 
(Code 1967, § 20-16; Ord. No. 1810, art. 4, 10-16-95; Ord. No. 1850, art. 2, 1-8-96; Ord. No. 2701, art. 12, 4-3-00) 
Sec. 18-28. - Meetings; bylaws. 
    The park and recreation advisory board shall have regular meetings on the first Monday of every month and special meetings when called by the chairman or four (4) members. The board may vote to change the date for its regular meetings for the convenience of its members, and the date may then be changed upon proper notification to the city council. The board shall adopt bylaws to govern the conduct of business. 
(Code 1967, § 20-17) 
Sec. 18-29. - Officers. 
    The parks and recreation advisory board shall meet annually during the month of October to elect officers. 
(Code 1967, § 20-18; Ord. No. 2701, art. 12, 4-3-00) 
Sec. 18-30. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The park and recreation advisory board shall act in an advisory capacity to the city council to review, promote and expedite development of existing and new public park and recreational facilities and activities. 
(b)  The park and recreation advisory board may investigate or study any problem or condition related to the construction, operation, maintenance or improvement of, or addition to a city park or related recreational facility. The park and recreation advisory board may meet, confer or negotiate with any individual, partnership, association, corporation, or local, state or federal agent or governmental organization. The park and recreation advisory board may present a proposed plan or design to the city council. 
(c)  The park and recreation advisory board may take an active part through its membership, subcommittees and such citizen committees as may be appointed by the park and recreation advisory board under authority of subsection (e) below to identify physical facilities suitable for public recreation, contact owners of such facilities to request permission for such use, recommend scheduling of recreation activities and notify the city manager and cooperating owners of other properties of such scheduled use; and to act in other respects as coordinators for public recreation, with the goal of utilizing all available city-owned and other property suitable for such use. 
(d)  The park and recreation advisory board shall keep the city council informed of its activities. 
(e)  The park and recreation advisory board shall have the power to appoint subcommittees of citizens who are not members of the park and recreation advisory board for set periods of time to work on specific projects relating to existing and new public parks, recreation facilities and activities. Such subcommittees will report their findings and recommendations to the park and recreation advisory board, which shall make any final report and recommendation to the city council. Each subcommittee will disband when work on its assigned project is completed. 
(f)  None of the provisions of subsections (a), (b), (c), (d), and (e) above shall apply to the Cape Jaycee Municipal Golf Course. 
(Code 1967, § 20-19) 
Sec. 18-31. - Park and recreation budget. 
    The park and recreation advisory board shall on or before the fifteenth day of April of each year, submit to the city manager its recommendations for park and recreation development programs. 
(Code 1967, § 20-20) 
Secs. 18-32-18-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CAPE JAYCEE MUNICIPAL GOLF COURSE ADVISORY BOARD[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; removal of members of boards and commissions, § 2-1. 

Sec. 18-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board means the Cape Jaycee Municipal Golf Course Advisory Board. 
    Golf course means the Cape Jaycee Municipal Golf Course. 
    Municipal golf course board means the Cape Jaycee Municipal Golf Course Advisory Board. 
(Code 1967, § 20-32) 
Sec. 18-52. - Created; membership. 
    There is hereby created an advisory board consisting of nine (9) citizens of the city and one (1) ex officio member to be determined as set out in section 18-53(c), which shall be known and designated as the "Cape Jaycee Municipal Golf Course Advisory Board." 
(Code 1967, § 20-31; Ord. No. 902, art. 1, 8-20-90; Ord. No. 1853, art. 1, 1-8-96) 
Sec. 18-53. - Qualifications of members; terms; ex officio members. 
(a)  One (1) member of the municipal golf course advisory board shall be a member of Cape Jaycees and designated by that organization as its representative on the municipal golf course advisory board. 
(b)  The city council shall appoint the nine (9) members of the municipal golf course advisory board by formal motion and majority action. Except as otherwise provided in section 2-98, members of the municipal golf course advisory board shall serve for terms of three (3) years. 
(c)  The mayor or a councilman designated by the mayor shall serve as an ex officio member of the municipal golf course advisory board and shall maintain liaison with the city council and city manager, but shall not have a vote in the decisions of the board. 
(Code 1967, § 20-33; Ord. No. 902, art. 2, 8-20-90; Ord. No. 1810, art. 5, 10-16-95; Ord. No. 1853, art. 2, 1-8-96; Ord. No. 2701, art. 13, 4-3-00) 
Sec. 18-54. - Meetings; bylaws. 
    The board shall meet, a minimum of six (6) times per year, and special meetings when called by the chairman or by five (5) members. The board shall adopt bylaws to govern conduct of business. 
(Ord. No. 5013, art. 1, 10-2-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5013, art. 1, adopted Oct. 2, 2017, repealed the former § 18-54 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 18-54 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1967, § 20-34; and Ord. No. 1853, art. 3, adopted Jan. 8, 1996. 
Sec. 18-55. - Officers. 
    The board shall meet annually during the month of November to elect officers. 
(Code 1967, § 20-35; Ord. No. 2701, art. 13, 4-3-00) 
Sec. 18-56. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The board shall act in an advisory capacity to the city council to review, promote and expedite development and use of city golf course facilities. 
(b)  The board may study any problem or condition relating to the construction, operation, maintenance or improvement of, or addition to the golf course or related facilities. The board may meet and confer with any individual, partnership, association, corporation, or local, state or federal agent or governmental organization. The board may present its findings and related recommendations to the city council. 
(c)  The board may make recommendations to the city council about scheduling of activities at the golf course and act in other respects as coordinator for public recreation at the golf course. 
(d)  The board shall keep the city council informed of its activities. 
(Code 1967, § 20-36) 
Sec. 18-57. - Golf course budget. 
    The board shall on or before the fifteenth day of April of each year, submit to the city manager its recommendations for golf course development programs. 
(Code 1967, § 20-37) 
Sec. 18-58. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1191, adopted June 15, 1992, repealed § 18-58, golf course fees, in its entirety. Former § 18-58 derived from § 20-38 of the Code of 1967. 
Chapter 20 - POLICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; civil defense, ch. 10; fire prevention and protection, ch. 11; municipal court, ch. 16; traffic, ch. 26; police department, § 2-53; enforcement of animal ordinance, § 6-5; private security patrol services, § 15-361 et seq.; traffic division, § 26-21 et seq.; enforcement of traffic regulations, § 26-51 et seq. 
State Law reference- Police, RSMo, Ch. 85 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Chief of police; rules, regulations. 
    The chief of police shall serve at the direction of the city manager and may be dismissed at will by the city manager. The chief is authorized to issue regulations and general orders pertaining to the operation of the police department. Such regulations and general orders shall be in conformity with the charter and ordinances of the city and may be rescinded by the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 23-2) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 20-2. - Police officer qualifications. 
    All members of the police department shall be at least twenty-one (21) years of age and residents of the state. Police officers shall meet such other qualifications as may be established by the city manager or the chief of police. 
(Code 1967, § 23-3) 
Sec. 20-3. - Police officer powers. 
    Any police officer shall have the power to arrest on view and without warrant any person he sees violating or who he has reasonable grounds to believe has violated any law of the state or any ordinance of the city. Police officers shall have the authority to respond to emergency situations outside the city limits. Police officers shall have all other powers necessary or incident to the performance of the police department function. 
    Under authority set forth in Section 70.837, RSMo, the Cape Girardeau Police Department is hereby authorized to respond and provide assistance as requested in any mutual aid or emergency aid request. 
(Code 1967, § 23-4; Ord. No. 1231, art. 1, 9-21-92; Ord. No. 1327, art. 1, 4-5-93) 
Sec. 20-4. - Disposition of unclaimed or abandoned personal property through public sale. 
(a)  This section applies to personal property in the possession of the police department, other than motor vehicles and weapons, the owner of which is unknown and cannot be located through reasonable efforts. 
(b)  The police chief shall make reasonable efforts to locate owners of personal property in the possession of the police department. 
(c)  The chief of police shall report to the city manager periodically on all unclaimed and abandoned personal property in possession of the police department and shall keep a current inventory of all such items. When unclaimed and abandoned personal property has been in the possession of the police department for thirty (30) consecutive days, it may be sold at public sale. Public sales shall be called from time to time as may be necessary by the police chief on authorization of the city manager. There shall be a minimum of one (1) public sale per year, with all proceeds going into the general revenue fund of the city. 
(d)  The public sale shall be held only after notice has been published for five (5) consecutive days in a newspaper of daily circulation; and shall be held at a public place designated by the police chief. Such notice shall include the date, time and place of such sale, but need not describe the property to be sold. 
(e)  Individuals may reclaim personal property up to the time of sale by a reasonable showing of ownership to the police chief or his designee. 
(Code 1967, § 23-4) 
Sec. 20-5. - Disposition of firearms, dangerous and deadly weapons. 
(a)  The police chief shall dispose of all unclaimed, abandoned, or forfeited firearms and dangerous and deadly weapons, and all firearms and dangerous and deadly weapons turned in by individuals, in the following manner: 
(1)  If the firearm or dangerous and deadly weapon is of the type designated as regulation equipment for the police department, then the firearm or dangerous and deadly weapon may be utilized as police equipment. 
(2)  If the firearm, or dangerous and deadly weapon is of historical value, or of an unusual nature, the firearm or dangerous and deadly weapon may be placed in the police department's display case for exhibition purposes only. 
(3)  All other firearms, or dangerous and deadly weapons shall either be destroyed in such a manner as to render them irreparable, and buried at the city's landfill or disposed of in any other lawful manner. 
(b)  The chief of police shall report to the city manager periodically on all nonregulation firearms and dangerous and deadly weapons in the possession of the police department and shall, in addition, keep a current inventory of all such items. 
(c)  No firearm shall be considered to be unclaimed or abandoned unless the firearm is in the possession of the police department for thirty (30) consecutive days. An individual may reclaim his firearm or dangerous and deadly weapon only upon a reasonable showing of ownership. No firearm or dangerous and deadly weapon shall be returned to a convicted felon, to a minor, or any other individual not having a legal right to possession. The thirty-consecutive-day requirement shall not begin to apply to a specific firearm or dangerous and deadly weapon when the item is being held for evidence in a trial, or other legal hearing, but shall only begin to run when the trial or legal hearing and all other legal processes involved are completed. 
(Code 1967, § 23-6) 
Cross reference- Offenses involving weapons and explosives, § 17-96 et seq. 
Secs. 20-6-20-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE RESERVES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 20-21. - Power of appointment. 
    The city manager is authorized to appoint police reserve officers. Officers so appointed shall meet the qualifications and shall have the powers set forth in this article. 
(Code 1967, § 23-16) 
Sec. 20-22. - Qualifications and training. 
(a)  Police reserve officers must be residents of the state, twenty-one (21) years of age or older. 
(b)  Police reserve officers shall qualify in the use of firearms semi-annually in accordance with standards established by the police department. Such officers may be required to participate in training programs sponsored and provided by the police department. 
(c)  Recruitment and selection of police reserve officers shall be based on minimum standards developed by the chief of police and approved by the city manager. 
(d)  Police reserve officers appointed after the effective date of Ordinance No. 252 must have successfully completed a course of basic training for peace officers in a program approved and accredited by the director of the state department of public safety. 
(Code 1967, § 23-17) 
Sec. 20-23. - Volunteer status. 
    Members of the police reserve shall receive no compensation from the city for their services. 
(Code 1967, § 23-18) 
Sec. 20-24. - Police reserve officer powers. 
    Police reserve officers who are on actual duty shall have the same powers as regular police officers. 
(Code 1967, § 23-19) 
Sec. 20-25. - Supervision. 
    The police reserve shall serve at the direction of the chief of police. 
(Code 1967, § 23-20) 
Sec. 20-26. - Rules and regulations. 
    The city manager and the chief of police may issue rules and regulations governing the police reserve. 
(Code 1967, § 23-21) 
Sec. 20-27. - Rank. 
    The city manager may authorize a rank structure for the police reserve. Police reserve officers, regardless of rank, shall be subordinate to regular police officers of any rank. 
(Code 1967, § 23-22) 
Sec. 20-28. - Dismissals. 
    The city manager may, at any time and without prior notification or hearing, terminate the membership of any person in the police reserve. 
(Code 1967, § 23-23) 
Sec. 20-29-20-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DEPUTIZATION OF SOUTHEAST MISSOURI STATE UNIVERSITY PUBLIC SAFETY OFFICERS 

Sec. 20-46. - Power of appointment. 
    The city manager is authorized to appoint Southeast Missouri State University public safety officers as deputy city police officers. Officers so appointed shall meet the qualifications and shall have the powers set forth in this article. 
(Code 1967, § 23-40) 
Sec. 20-47. - Qualifications. 
(a)  Southeast Missouri State University public safety officers appointed as deputy city police officers must be state residents, twenty-one (21) years of age or older, who have successfully completed a course of basic training for peace officers in a program approved and accredited by the director of the state department of public safety. 
(b)  Southeast Missouri State University public safety officers appointed as deputy city police officers shall qualify in the use of firearms semi-annually in accordance with standards established by the police department. Such officers may be required to participate in training programs sponsored and provided by the police department. 
(c)  Recruitment and selection of Southeast Missouri State University public safety officers to be deputized by the city as city police officers shall be based on minimum standards approved by the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 23-41) 
Sec. 20-48. - Arrest power. 
    Any Southeast Missouri State University public safety officer appointed as deputy city police officer shall have the power to arrest on view and without warrant any person he sees violating or who he has reasonable grounds to believe has violated any law of the state or any ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 23-42) 
Sec. 20-49. - Supervision. 
    Southeast Missouri State University public safety officers appointed as deputy city police officers shall be employees of Southeast Missouri State University and shall routinely receive direct supervision from their superiors in the Southeast Missouri State University Department of Public Safety. 
(Code 1967, § 23-43) 
Sec. 20-50. - Rules and regulations. 
    The city manager and the chief of police may issue rules and regulations pertaining to deputy city police officers. 
(Code 1967, § 23-44) 
Sec. 20-51. - Revocation of deputization. 
    The city manager may at any time and without prior notification or hearing revoke the appointment of any Southeast Missouri State University public safety officer as a deputy city police officer. Except in extreme situations, however, the city manager shall exercise this power only after discussions with appropriate university officials. 
(Code 1967, § 23-45) 
Sec. 20-52. - Insurance. 
(a)  No Southeast Missouri State University public safety officer shall be appointed as deputy city police officer unless Southeast Missouri State University shall carry liability insurance to cover the activities of all public safety officers deputized by the city in the minimum amount of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) each person, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) each occurrence, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) annual aggregate. Such insurance shall name the city and its officials and employees as insureds. The city manager shall revoke the appointments of all Southeast Missouri State University public safety officers as deputy city police officers if such insurance is not provided at all times and evidence of such insurance provided to the city manager. 
(b)  Southeast Missouri State University shall not be required to meet the insurance requirements of subsection (a) of this section for such time as the conduct of its public safety officers arising out of and performed in connection with their official duties on behalf of the university are covered by the "State Legal Expense Fund" created by RSMo 105.711. 
(Code 1967, § 23-46) 
Secs. 20-53-20-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MAJOR CASE SQUAD[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 956, adopted Dec. 19, 1990, amended the 1967 Code by adding ch. 23, art. IV, §§ 23-50-23-54, thereto. The editor has included the new provisions as art. IV, §§ 20-71-20-75, at his discretion. 

Sec. 20-71. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a major case squad and the City of Cape Girardeau police department is hereby authorized to cooperate with the Cape Girardeau County sheriff's department and prosecuting attorney's office, the City of Jackson, Missouri's police department, the Bollinger County sheriff's department and prosecuting attorney's office, the Scott County sheriff's department and prosecuting attorney's office and the Missouri State Highway Patrol in the formation of a major case squad for the purpose of intensive professional investigation of a certain individual crime which may occur in their general geographical area. 
(Ord. No. 951, art. 1, 12-19-90) 
Sec. 20-72. - Expenses. 
    Expenses of the major case squad may be paid by the individual political subdivisions forming the major case squad. The payment of expenses by the city shall be subject to the direction of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 956, art. 1, 12-19-90) 
Sec. 20-73. - Activation. 
    The major case squad shall operate and be activated upon the request of the county sheriff or police chief of the political subdivision where the crime occurred. 
(Ord. No. 956, art. 1, 12-19-90) 
Sec. 20-74. - Power of arrest. 
    Whenever any peace officer is duly authorized as a member of a major case squad, such officer shall have the power to arrest anywhere within this state. This power shall only be exercised during the times the peace officer is an active member of an active major case squad and only within the scope of the investigation on which the squad is working. 
(Ord. No. 956, art. 1, 12-19-90) 
Sec. 20-75. - Notice to other jurisdictions. 
    Prior to the initiation of a major case squad investigation in a political subdivision other than where the crime occurred, a member of the major case squad shall notify the chief law enforcement officer of the political subdivision in which the investigation is to be conducted, or a designated agent thereof. 
(Ord. No. 956, art. 1, 12-19-90) 
Chapter 21 - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS AND SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, ch. 24; water and sewers, ch. 29. 
State Law reference- Public improvements, RSMo, § 71.290 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 21-1-21-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LAND ACQUISITION AND PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 21-26. - Acquisition of property interests. 
    The city shall have full power and authority to acquire interest in real estate for any public use by gift, devise, purchase, lease, dedication or the exercise of the power of eminent domain by condemnation proceedings. 
(Code 1967, § 23A-1) 
Sec. 21-27. - Condemnation procedure. 
    Except where otherwise provided by law, the city in exercising the power of eminent domain shall follow the procedures set forth in the Missouri Supreme Court Rules. 
(Code 1967, § 23A-2) 
Sec. 21-28. - Public improvements. 
    Except where otherwise provided by law, the construction of public improvements may be authorized by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 23A-3) 
Sec. 21-29. - Funding public improvements. 
    Public improvements may be funded by any lawful method or combination of methods. 
(Code 1967, § 23A-4) 
Secs. 21-30-21-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SPECIAL ASSESSMENT PROJECTS 

Sec. 21-46. - Governing law. 
    The procedure for levying, collecting and enforcing the payment of special assessments for public improvements or special tax bills evidencing such assessments shall be governed by RSMo. 88.811-88.861 and by the provisions of this article. However, the specific procedures for levying, collecting and enforcing the payment of special assessments for water mains, shall additionally be governed either by RSMo. 88.650-88.663, or by creating a special assessment water district and using the procedure in RSMo. 88.832-88.861. The choice of which special assessment procedure shall be used for water mains shall be left to the sole discretion of the city council or its designee. 
(Code 1967, § 23A-11; Ord. No. 2219, art. 1, 8-18-97) 
Sec. 21-47. - Advancement of city funds. 
    The city council may provide that the costs of any special assessment project be advanced from city funds and that the special tax bills issued thereafter be made payable to the city. 
(Code 1967, § 23A-12) 
Sec. 21-48. - Street improvement projects; right of remonstrance. 
    The city council shall not impose special assessments in excess of fifty (50) percent of the total cost of any street improvement project exceeding twelve hundred (1,200) feet in length where a valid written protest against the improvement has been filed with the city clerk within ten (10) days after the final publication required by RSMo 88.812. In order to be valid, the protest must be signed by a majority of the owners of the abutting lands who reside within the city limits who would be liable for the cost of the improvement, and who shall own a majority of the front feet abutting on the street or part of the street proposed to be improved. 
(Ord. No. 909, art. 1(23A-13), 8-20-90) 
Sec. 21-49. - Engineer's estimate. 
    The city engineer shall prepare a cost estimate on every project for which a special assessment is to be levied under the terms of this article. The city may not accept any bid for construction of that project which exceeds the engineer's cost estimate, unless all bids properly received exceeded that estimate. In such a case, the bid accepted by the city may exceed the engineer's estimate by up to ten (10) percent of that estimate, but only if that bid was the lowest bid received on that project. 
(Ord. No. 3224, art. 1, 9-15-03) 
Secs. 21-50-21-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - VACATING CITY STREETS 

Sec. 21-66. - Power to vacate. 
    The city council may, by ordinance, vacate any city street or any interest the city has in any real estate after first holding a public hearing as provided in this article and after finding that such vacation is in the public interest. 
(Code 1967, § 23A-34) 
Sec. 21-67. - Public hearing. 
    The city council shall hold a public hearing to consider vacating a city street or the city's interest in any real estate whenever it receives a petition to vacate signed by each owner of property abutting the street sought to be vacated or abutting the property in which the city's interest is sought to be vacated. The city council may, on its own motion, hold a hearing to consider vacating any city street or the city's interest in any real estate. At least ten (10) days' notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. All interested parties shall be afforded the opportunity at the hearing to speak in favor of or in opposition to the proposed vacation. 
(Code 1967, § 23A-35) 
Chapter 22 - SOLID WASTE AND WEEDS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, ch. 11; health and sanitation, ch. 13; licenses and business regulations, ch. 15; water and sewers, ch. 29; burning, air pollution regulations, § 3-9 et seq.; removal of dead animals, § 6-2; refuse handling in travel trailer camps and mobile home parks, § 27-37; insect and rodent control in travel trailer camps and mobile home parks, § 27-38. 
State Law reference- Solid waste, RSMo, § 260.200 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1-22-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STORAGE, COLLECTION, TRANSPORTATION, PROCESSING AND DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE 

Sec. 22-26. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article the following terms shall be deemed to have the meaning indicated below: 
    Approved incinerator means an incinerator which complies with all current regulations of the Missouri Air Conservation Commission and the requirements of the city. 
    Bulky rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of combustible and/or noncombustible waste materials from dwelling units, commercial, industrial, institutional or agricultural establishments which are either too large or too heavy to be safely and conveniently loaded in solid waste collection vehicles by solid waste collectors, with the equipment available therefor. 
    City staff means the public works department of the city. 
    Collection means the removal and transportation of solid waste from its place of storage to its place of processing or disposal. 
    Commercial establishment means any commercial, industrial, institutional or agricultural establishment, and any multiple housing facility or multiple housing complex with more than three (3) dwelling units. 
    Demolition and construction waste means waste materials from the construction or destruction of residential, industrial or commercial structures. 
    Disposal facility means solid waste transfer station, landfill disposal site or any other approved site for the handling and disposition of solid waste. 
    Disposable solid waste containers means disposable plastic sacks with a capacity of twenty (20) to thirty-two (32) gallons specifically designed for storage of solid waste. 
    Dumpster means any container, receptacle, compactor unit, trailer, roll-off, or similar unit with or without wheels that is used for temporary storage, containment, or transport of refuse, debris, trash, garbage, food waste, solid waste, recyclable material, incidental demolition debris, or other discarded or like materials. It shall not apply to ordinary household trash cans of a volume of sixty-four (64) gallons or less, recycling receptacles of ninety-six (96) gallons or less. 
    Dwelling unit means any room or group of rooms located within a structure and forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used, or are intended to be used, for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. 
    Garbage means putrescible animal or vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, serving or consumption of food. 
    Hazardous wastes means and includes, but is not limited to, pathological wastes, explosive wastes, pesticides, pesticide containers, toxic or radioactive materials. 
    Multiple housing complex means a group of multiple housing facilities under the same ownership and control, located in the same and contiguous geographical area. 
    Multiple housing facility means a housing facility containing more than one (1) dwelling unit under one (1) roof. 
    Occupant means any person who, alone or jointly or severally with others shall be in actual possession of any dwelling unit or of any other improved real property, either as owner or as tenant. 
    Operating fee means costs incurred by the city for equipment and personnel to provide refuse service. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision or organization of any kind, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. 
    Processing means incinerating, composting, baling, shredding, salvaging, compacting and other processes whereby solid waste characteristics are modified or solid waste quantity is reduced. 
    Recyclables are items collected by recycling crews which have been deemed acceptable for recycling by the city staff. 
    Recycling center means a facility for drop off and processing of recyclable products. 
    Recycling containers are containers that provide for access, separation, and content identification for the collection of recyclable products. 
    Refuse means solid waste. 
    Solid waste means unwanted or discarded waste materials in a solid or semisolid state, including, but not limited to, garbage, ashes, street refuse, rubbish, dead animals, animal and agricultural wastes, yard wastes, discarded appliances, special wastes, industrial wastes, and demolition and construction wastes. 
(1)  Commercial solid waste. Solid waste resulting from the operation of any commercial, industrial, institutional or agricultural establishment, and any multiple housing facilities with more than three (3) dwelling units, or multiple housing complexes with more than three (3) dwelling units. 
(2)  Residential solid waste. Solid waste resulting from the maintenance and operation of dwelling units, excluding multiple housing facilities with more than three (3) dwelling units, and multiple housing complexes with more than three (3) dwelling units. 
    Solid waste containers means receptacles used by any person to store solid wastes during the interval between solid waste collections. 
    Solid waste disposal means the process of discarding or getting rid of unwanted material. In particular, the final disposition of solid waste by man. 
    Solid waste management means the entire solid waste system of storage, collection, transportation, processing and disposal. 
    Storage means keeping, maintaining or storing solid waste from the time of its production until the time of its collection. 
    Tipping fee means the per ton cost of operation of the transfer station and cost for transportation and disposal. 
    Yard waste includes all grass clippings, leaves, yard and garden vegetation, tree limbs, and brush. 
(Code 1967, § 13-11; Ord. No. 666, § 1, 2-15-89; Ord. No. 874, arts. 1, 2, 6-18-90; Ord. No. 890, arts. 1, 2, 7-16-90; Ord. No. 1194, §§ 1, 2, 6-15-92; Ord. No. 4948, art. 1, 3-20-17) 
Sec. 22-27. - City to provide containers. 
    The city shall provide each residential solid waste customer with one (1) sixty-four (64) gallon container for the storage of all solid waste except bulky rubbish, demolition and construction waste, and one (1) ninety-six (96) gallon cart for the storage of all accepted recycling materials as determined by the public works director, except glass and yard waste or other materials as may be determined by the public works director. Each occupant shall place all solid waste to be collected in the city-provided sixty-four (64) gallon container and all recyclable materials in the city-provided ninety-six (96) gallon container. Each occupant shall not damage, abuse or misuse any container provided by the city and shall keep the area surrounding such container in a clean, neat and sanitary condition. The city may provide each residential solid waste customer with households consisting of one (1) or two (2) persons with options for sizes smaller than the standard sizes otherwise established in this section. 
(Code 1967, § 13-12; Ord. No. 4110, art. 1, 3-15-10) 
Sec. 22-28. - Commercial establishments to provide containers. 
    Every commercial establishment shall provide sufficient and adequate containers, to be approved by the city staff, for the storage of all solid waste except bulky rubbish and demolition and construction waste to serve such commercial establishment. 
(Code 1967, § 13-13; Ord. No. 4110, art. 2, 3-15-10) 
Sec. 22-29. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Article 3 of Ord. No. 4110, adopted March 15, 2010, repealed § 22-29 which pertained to residential container specifications, and derived from § 13-14 of the 1967 Code. 
Sec. 22-30. - Tree limbs; how collected. 
    All tree limbs and brush shall be securely tied in bundles not larger than forty-eight (48) inches long and eighteen (18) inches in diameter. The weight of any individual bundle shall not exceed seventy-five (75) pounds. 
(Code 1967, § 13-15; Ord. No. 1194, § 3, 6-15-92) 
Sec. 22-31. - Demolition and construction wastes not to be collected. 
    Demolition and construction wastes shall be collected only by contractual arrangement with the city or by other persons authorized by the city to collect such demolition and construction wastes pursuant to this chapter and must not be disposed of in regularly scheduled residential collections. 
(Ord. No. 666, § 2, 2-15-89; Ord. No. 4110, art. 4, 3-15-10) 
Sec. 22-32. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Article 5 of Ord. No. 4110, adopted March 15, 2010, repealed § 22-32 which pertained to when containers collected, and derived from § 13-17 of the 1967 Code. 
Sec. 22-33. - Collection of solid waste; residential and commercial. 
(a)  Every owner or occupant of a residential dwelling unit within the city limits shall receive solid waste collection service and tender payment therefor in accordance with the fees established in this article. The owners and occupants of individual premises receiving solid waste collection service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay such fees. The city shall have the power to file civil suit against owners, occupants or both to recover all sums due and, in addition thereto, reasonable attorney's fees. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of each commercial establishment to provide for collection of all solid waste produced upon such premises, and to dispose of such waste in a lawful manner. 
(c)  All commercial waste and recyclable containers shall be used in such a way as to prevent blowing or spreading of refuse in any way. 
(Ord. No. 5101 , art. 1, 8-20-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5101 , art. 1, adopted Aug. 20, 2018, repealed the former § 22-33 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 22-33 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1967, § 13-18; and Ord. No. 4110, art. 6, adopted March 15, 2010. 
Sec. 22-34. - Bulky rubbish collected; how. 
    All solid waste from premises to which collection services are provided by the city shall be collected, except as elsewhere provided in this chapter, and except for bulky rubbish, provided, however, that bulky rubbish may be collected according to regulations and charges to be made and promulgated by the city staff as hereinafter provided. Bulky rubbish shall not be collected upon regular collection days, but shall be collected upon request to the city staff and according to procedures established by the city staff. Nothing in this chapter shall require the city to collect any bulky rubbish that the city staff determines to be harmful to its collection equipment, or that cannot be adequately disposed of by the disposal methods utilized by the city. 
(Code 1967, § 13-19; Ord. No. 1032, art. 1, 6-17-91) 
Sec. 22-35. - Waste containers; where placed. 
(a)  All residential waste and recyclable containers shall be placed within three (3) feet of the curb or edge of roadway, or alley, where ordered by the city staff, for collection, except as elsewhere provided for in this chapter. Such containers shall be placed at the curb, or edge of roadway, or alley, on or twelve (12) hours prior to the day of collection, and removed on the same day within a reasonable time. Such containers shall be used in such a way as to prevent blowing or spreading of refuse in any way and be stored on private property. 
(b)  All commercial waste containers shall be placed upon private property, accessible for collection and in a well-drained area. 
(c)  The contents of residential waste containers shall be kept in such condition that they can, at all times, be readily and fully removable by the city. 
(Ord. No. 5101 , art. 2, 8-20-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5101 , art. 2, adopted Aug. 20, 2018, repealed the former § 22-35 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 22-35 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1967, § 13-20; Ord. No. 1032, art. 2, adopted June 17, 1991; Ord. No. 1194, § 4, adopted June 15, 1992; and Ord. No. 4110, art. 7, adopted March 15, 2010. 
Sec. 22-36. - Collection frequency. 
    All residential solid wastes shall be collected at least twice weekly, once for regular trash collection and once for collection [of] recyclable materials, on the days designated and in the manner required by the public works director to meet the objectives of the city's solid waste management plan. 
(Code 1967, § 13-21; Ord. No. 1194, § 5, 6-15-92) 
Sec. 22-37. - Collection vehicles; condition. 
    All collection vehicles shall be maintained in a safe, clean and sanitary condition, and shall be so constructed, maintained and operated as to prevent spillage of solid waste therefrom. All vehicles used for collection of solid waste shall be constructed with watertight bodies and with covers which shall be an integral part of the vehicle or shall be a separate cover of suitable material with fasteners designed to secure all sides of the cover to the vehicle and shall be secured whenever the vehicle is transporting solid waste, or, as an alternate, the entire bodies thereof shall be enclosed, with only loading hoppers exposed. No solid waste shall be transported in the loading hoppers. Before any permit for the collection of solid wastes shall be issued, the city staff shall inspect and approve applicant's equipment according to this section. If the applicant's equipment shall not meet these requirements, the permit shall not be issued. 
(Code 1967, § 13-22; Ord. No. 666, § 3, 2-15-89) 
Sec. 22-38. - Disposal of rock and earth. 
    No permits of any kind shall be required for the removal, hauling or disposal of earth and rock material from grading or excavation activities; however, all such material shall be conveyed in vehicles so constructed and maintained that none of the material being transported shall spill upon the public rights-of-way. Transportation and disposal of demolition and construction wastes shall be in accordance with later sections. 
(Code 1967, § 13-23) 
Sec. 22-39. - Disposal of waste; fee. 
(a)  Solid waste shall be disposed of at a processing facility or disposal area approved by the city and shall comply with the requirement of the state department of natural resources. The city may classify certain wastes as hazardous and shall order disposal in a manner which will meet all local, state and federal regulations. 
(b)  Haulers who dispose of less than twenty (20) tons of solid waste per week at the city disposal facility shall pay a rate of sixty-two dollars ($62.00) per ton plus fuel surcharge, if applicable. The applicable fee shall be increased by twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each load that is not properly covered or secured in accordance with state and local law. Private haulers who regularly use the disposal facility and who regularly dispose of more than twenty (20) tons of solid waste per week at the city disposal facility shall have a rate established by contract based on the operating costs. The charge per ton will be increased when the previous month's average per gallon diesel fuel price exceeds three dollars and seventy-five cents ($3.75). The charge per ton will be increased by one hundred percent (100%) of the difference between the previous month's average per gallon diesel fuel price and three dollars and seventy-five cents ($3.75). All surcharges will be rounded up to the next cent. Average per gallon diesel fuel costs will be the average of the Midwest Region Index as published by the U. S. Department of Energy. 
(c)  Fuel surcharge. The monthly solid waste collection fee for residential customers shall be increased when the previous month's average per gallon diesel fuel price exceeds three dollars and seventy-five cents ($3.75). The charge will be increased by twenty-five (25) percent of the difference between the previous month's average per gallon diesel fuel price and three dollars and seventy-five cents ($3.75). All surcharges will be rounded up to the next cent average per gallon diesel fuel costs will be the average of the Midwest Region Index as published by the U.S. Department of Energy. 
(Code 1967, § 13-24; Ord. No. 666, § 4, 2-15-89; Ord. No. 1032, art. 3, 6-17-91; Ord. No. 1194, § 6, 6-15-92; Ord. No. 1354, art. 3, 6-7-93; Ord. No. 1559, art. 1, 6-20-94; Ord. No. 2176, art. 1, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 2792, art. 1, 9-25-00; Ord. No. 3498, art. 1, 6-20-05; Ord. No. 3773, art. 1, 12-18-06; Ord. No. 3823, art. 1, 6-18-07; Ord. No. 3873, art. 1, 12-3-07; Ord. No. 3925, art. 1, 6-16-08; Ord. No. 4040, art. 1, 6-15-09; Ord. No. 4132, art. 1, 6-21-10; Ord. No. 4243, art. 1, 6-20-11; Ord. No. 4323, art. 1, 6-18-12; Ord. No. 4470, art. 1, 6-17-13; Ord. No. 4660, art. 1, 1-20-15; Ord. No. 4718, art. 1, 6-15-15; Ord. No. 4863, art. 1, 6-20-16; Ord. No. 4981, art. 1, 6-19-17; Ord. No. 5087 , art. 1, 6-18-18) 
Sec. 22-40. - Permit-Required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of solid waste within the city limits of the city, without first obtaining an annual permit therefor from the city; provided, however, that this provision shall not be deemed to apply to employees of the holder of any such permit. Collection vehicles of persons holding permits shall have their names, addresses, and permit numbers painted on both sides of such vehicles in letters of at least three (3) inches, in a contrasting color to that of the vehicle. 
(Code 1967, § 13-25) 
Sec. 22-41. - Same-Liability insurance necessary. 
    No permit required by section 22-40 shall be issued until and unless the applicant therefor, in addition to other requirements set forth, shall file and maintain with the city staff a certificate of insurance covering all operations of such applicant pertaining to such business and all vehicles to be operated in the conduct thereof, in the amount of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each person injured or killed, and in the amount of not less than eight hundred thousand dollars ($800,000.00) in the event of injury or death of two (2) or more persons in any single accident, and in the amount of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for damage to property. Should such policy be cancelled, the city staff shall be notified of such cancellation by the insurance carrier in writing not less than ten (10) days prior to the effective date of such cancellation, and provisions to that effect shall be incorporated in any such policy, which shall also place upon the company writing such policy the duty to give such notice. 
(Ord. No. 666, § 5, 2-15-89) 
Sec. 22-42. - Same-Information required. 
    Each applicant for any permit required by section 22-40 shall state in his application therefor: 
(1)  The nature of the permit desired, as to collect, transport, process or dispose of solid waste or any combination thereof; 
(2)  The characteristics of solid waste to be collected, transported, processed or disposed; 
(3)  The number of solid waste vehicles to be operated thereunder; 
(4)  The precise location of solid waste processing or disposal facilities to be used; 
(5)  Boundaries of the collection area; and 
(6)  Such other information as required by the city staff. 
(Code 1967, § 13-27) 
Sec. 22-43. - Same-When issued. 
(a)  If the application for a license required by section 22-40 shows that the applicant will collect, transport, process or dispose of solid wastes without hazard to the public health or damage to the environment and in conformity with the laws of the state and this article, the city staff shall issue the permit authorized by this article. The permit shall be issued for a period of one (1) year, and each applicant shall pay therefor a fee of forty dollars ($40.00). If in the opinion of the city staff, modifications can be made to the application regarding service, equipment or mode of operation, so as to bring the application within the intent of this article; the city may notify the applicant in writing setting forth the modification to be made and the time in which it shall be done. 
(b)  If the applicant fails to meet all conditions, he shall be notified in writing that the permit applied for was denied. The annual permit may be renewed upon payment of fees, except where modifications in the applicant's business have occurred. If modifications have occurred then the applicant must reapply. 
(Code 1967, § 13-28; Ord. No. 666, § 6, 2-15-89; Ord. No. 4110, art. 8, 3-15-10; Ord. No. 4510, art. 10, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 22-44. - Inspection. 
    In order to insure compliance with the laws of this state, this article and the rules and regulations authorized herein, the city staff is authorized to inspect all phases of solid waste management within the city. Violations shall be reported to the city manager and may be grounds for the suspension or revocation of the permit, depending upon the circumstances involved. Nothing in this section shall be construed to in any way limit, amend or alter any provisions in the public nuisance ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 13-29) 
Sec. 22-45. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  The city staff shall make, amend, revoke and enforce reasonable and necessary rules and regulations governing, but not limited to: 
(1)  Preparation, drainage and wrapping of garbage deposited in solid waste containers. 
(2)  Specifications for solid waste containers, including the type, composition, equipment, size and shape thereof. 
(3)  Identification of solid waste containers and of the covers thereof, and of equipment thereto appertaining, if any. 
(4)  Weight limitations on the combined weight of solid waste containers and the contents thereof, and weight and size limitations on bundles of solid waste too large for solid waste containers. 
(5)  Storage of solid waste in solid waste containers. 
(6)  Sanitation, maintenance and replacement of solid waste containers. 
(7)  Schedules of and routes for collection of solid waste. 
(8)  Collection points of solid waste containers. 
(9)  Collection and disposal of solid waste. 
(10)  Processing facilities and fees for the use thereof. 
(11)  Disposal facilities and fees for the use thereof. 
(12)  Records of quantity and type of wastes received at processing and/or disposal facilities. 
(13)  Handling of special wastes such as toxic wastes, sludges, ashes, agriculture, construction, bulky items, tires, automobiles, oils, greases, etc. 
(b)  The city collector is hereby authorized to make and promulgate reasonable and necessary rules and regulations for the billing and collection of solid waste collection and/or disposal service charges, as hereinafter provided for. 
(Code 1967, § 13-30) 
Sec. 22-46. - Prohibited practices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Deposit solid waste in any solid waste container other than his own, without the written consent of the owner of such container and/or with the intent of avoiding payment of the service charge hereinafter provided for solid waste collection and disposal. 
(2)  Interference in any manner with solid waste collection equipment, or with solid waste collectors in the lawful performance of their duties as such, whether such equipment or collectors shall be those of the city, or those of a solid waste collection agency operating under contract with the city. 
(3)  Burn solid waste unless an approved incinerator is provided or unless a variance has been obtained from the appropriate air pollution control agency. 
(4)  Dispose of solid waste at any facility or location which is not approved by the city and the state department of health. 
(5)  Engage in the business of collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of solid waste within the city limits of the city without a permit from the city, or operate under any expired permit, or operate after a permit has been suspended or revoked. 
(Code 1967, § 13-31) 
Sec. 22-47. - Residential solid waste collection fees. 
(a)  Basic monthly charge. The basic monthly solid waste collection fee for residential customers shall be twenty dollars and seventy-five cents ($20.75) per month per dwelling unit. Residential back door service may be provided on a contract basis subject to fees based on the additional operating costs associated with providing such service. Such basic charge shall include the following services: 
(1)  Collection of all waste or recycling in the city-provided containers. 
(2)  Bulk waste collection program. 
(3)  Fall leaf collection program. 
(b)  Additional container. Customers who receive a second sixty-four (64) gallon container for solid waste storage and collection shall pay an additional twenty dollars and seventy-five cents ($20.75) per month per dwelling unit plus the basic monthly charge established in this section. 
(c)  Fuel surcharge. The monthly solid waste collection fee for residential customers shall be increased when the previous month's average per gallon diesel fuel price exceeds three dollars and seventy-five cents ($3.75). The charge will be increased by twenty-five (25) percent of the difference between the previous month's average per gallon diesel fuel price and three dollars and seventy-five cents ($3.75). All surcharges will be rounded up to the next cent. Average per gallon diesel fuel costs will be the U. S. Average as published by the U.S. Energy Information Administration. 
(Ord. No. 5087 , art. 2, 6-18-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5087 , art. 2, adopted June 18, 2018, repealed the former § 22-47 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 22-47 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 4981, art. 2, adopted June 19, 2017. 
Sec. 22-48. - Billing; payment; delinquency; penalty. 
(a)  The city finance director, or such other officer or representative of the city as may be designated from time to time, shall be responsible for calculating the amount of and rendering bills for the fees established in this article. 
(b)  All service bills shall be due and payable in full fourteen (14) days from the date the bill was rendered and shall be considered delinquent after twenty-one (21) days. If the last day for remittance falls upon a weekend or holiday, or any other day when the offices of the department, regularly used for the payment of customer bills, are not open to the general public, the final payment date shall be extended through to the close of the next business day. The date of payment for remittance through the mail shall be the date on which the department receives the remittance. All accounts which become delinquent shall be charged a ten (10) percent penalty. 
(Code 1967, § 13-34; Ord. No. 1194, §§ 8, 9, 6-15-92; Ord. No. 1614, art. 1, 9-19-94) 
Sec. 22-49. - Termination of solid waste collection service. 
    In the event an account declared delinquent has not been paid in full within one (1) month of the initial due date, the city may terminate solid waste collection service to such premises. 
(Code 1967, § 13-35) 
Sec. 22-50. - Failure to pay fees; penalty. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person properly charged for fees established in this article to fail to pay such fees and such offense shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Code 1967, § 13-36) 
Sec. 22-51. - Penalties. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, any person violating any of the provisions of this article, or any lawful rules or regulations promulgated pursuant thereto, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00); provided, that each day's violation thereof shall be a separate offense for the purpose hereof. 
(Code 1967, § 13-37) 
Sec. 22-52. - Dumpster. 
(a)  General. Because the unregulated maintenance and operation of dumpsters in residential lots containing three (3) or fewer dwelling units and in the city rights-of-way presents a threat to the public health, safety, environment, and general welfare, no person, business, or any other entity shall operate, keep, store, or maintain a dumpster on a residential lot containing three (3) or fewer dwelling units or in the city right-of-way without first obtaining the dumpster permit required by this chapter, and shall maintain said dumpster in accordance with said permit, this chapter, and any regulation promulgated hereunder. 
(b)  Permit required. No dumpster shall be used in a residential lot containing three (3) or fewer dwelling units or in the city rights-of-way without first obtaining a permit from the city manager or his/her designee. If a dumpster is to be located upon a public way, then an on-street dumpster permit must be obtained. If a dumpster is to be located in a residential lot containing three (3) or fewer dwelling units, then a residential dumpster permit must be obtained. If the city manager or his/her designee determines that a submitted dumpster permit application is accurate and adequate to keep the site free from debris, refuse, trash, solid waste or like material that is injurious to the public health, safety, and environment, the city manager or his/her designee may issue a permit for the dumpster. Performance of the activities scheduled in the dumpster permit shall be a condition of the permit and nonperformance of the activities scheduled in the dumpster permit shall be a violation of the permit and conditions of this chapter. 
(c)  On-street dumpster permit. Dumpster may initially be placed on the public right-of-way for a maximum of two (2) weeks. An extension may be requested for a valid reason for a period of one (1) week. All dumpsters placed on the public right-of-way shall have sufficient reflective markings to be visible after nightfall. 
(d)  Residential dumpster permit. Dumpster may initially be placed on the residential lot containing three (3) or fewer dwelling units for a maximum of thirty (30) days. An extension may be requested for a valid reason for a period of thirty (30) days. All dumpsters placed on lots containing three (3) or fewer dwelling units shall be maintained and serviced so that refuse does not overflow. The resident, property owner, and the dumpster company are all responsible persons under this section. 
(Ord. No. 4948, art. 2, 3-20-17) 
Secs. 22-53-22-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LITTER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Throwing injurious refuse on streets, § 24-11. 
State Law reference- Solid waste disposal, RSMo, § 260.200 et seq. 

Sec. 22-71. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the Cape Girardeau Anti-Litter Ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-1) 
Sec. 22-72. - Penalties for violation. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined an amount not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or be not less than one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) and imprisoned in the city jail for a period not exceeding three (3) months or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue may constitute a separate offense and may be punishable as such hereunder. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-2; Ord. No. 4517, art. 5, 12-2-13) 
Sec. 22-73. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein: 
    Accumulated litter means litter of an amount and degree so as to constitute a nuisance. 
    Aircraft means any contrivance now known or hereafter invented, used or designated for navigation or for flight in the air. The word "aircraft" shall include helicopters and lighter-than-air dirigibles and balloons. 
    Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation and cooking and consumption of food. 
    Handbill means any printed or written matter, any sample, or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter or literature. 
    Litter means "garbage," "refuse" and "rubbish" and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. 
    Newspaper means a publication of general circulation printed, distributed and subscribed to by the recipient which contains either news, opinions, advertisements or other items of general interest, and in addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four (4) issues per year, and sold to the public. 
    Park means a park, reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other public area in the city, owned and/or used by the city and developed to active or passive recreation. 
    Private premises means any dwelling, house, building, or other structure, designed or used either wholly or in part for private purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building or other structure. 
    Public place means any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds, and buildings. 
    Receptacle means a litter storage and collection container constructed and maintained so as to prevent litter from escaping therefrom and which is offered for the purpose of receiving litter. 
    Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles and solid market and industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-3) 
Sec. 22-74. - Litter in public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk, or other public place within the city except in receptacles, or in an official city dump. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-4) 
Sec. 22-75. - Placement of litter in receptacles so as to prevent scattering. 
    Persons placing litter in receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-5) 
Sec. 22-76. - Sweeping litter into gutters prohibited. 
    No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street, or other public place within the city, the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-6) 
Sec. 22-77. - Litter thrown by persons in vehicles. 
    No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the city or upon private property. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-7) 
Cross reference- Traffic, ch. 26. 
Sec. 22-78. - Truck loads causing litter. 
(a)  No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded so as to prevent any load contents, or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or other public place or upon private property in an amount so as to constitute a nuisance unless the person removes such load contents or litter from said street, alley, public or private place at the completion of the working day, or at least once each calendar working day. 
(b)  No person shall drive or move any vehicle or truck within the city, the wheels, or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley or other public place, mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter, or foreign matter of any kind in an amount so as to constitute a nuisance unless the person removes the mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter, or foreign matter from said street, alley or public place at the completion of the working day. 
(c)  Any person who creates a nuisance on account of violation of section (a) or (b) above must abate that nuisance immediately and may not wait until the completion of the working day whenever a duly commissioned police officer of the city determines that such nuisance is an immediate hazard for persons who travel upon said street, alley or other public place or said private property. If a police officer makes a determination that the nuisance constitutes an immediate hazard, he may order the responsible person to begin immediate clean-up and abatement of the nuisance and should such person fail or refuse to comply with the police officer's order, the city shall have the right and authority to proceed to correct and remove said immediate hazard and charge the expense thereof to the person who is in violation of section (a) or (b ) above. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-8; Ord. No. 1222, art. 1, 8-17-92) 
Sec. 22-79. - Litter in parks. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any park within the city except in receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any street or other public place or upon private property. Where receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere as provided herein. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-9) 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, ch. 18. 
Sec. 22-80. - Litter in lakes and fountains. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any fountain, pond, lake, stream, bay or other body of water in a park or elsewhere within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-10) 
Sec. 22-81. - Throwing or distributing handbills in public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any handbill in or upon any sidewalk, street or other public place within the city; provided, however, that it shall not be unlawful on any sidewalk, street or other public place within the city for a person to hand out or distribute a handbill to any person willing to accept it. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-11) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, ch. 15. 
Sec. 22-82. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Article 1 of Ord. No. 4389, adopted Nov. 5, 2012, repealed § 22-82, placing handbills on or in vehicles, which derived from § 16A-12 of the 1967 Code. 
Sec. 22-83. - Depositing handbill on uninhabited or vacant premises. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any handbill in or upon any private premises which are temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-13) 
Sec. 22-84. - Prohibiting distributing of handbills where property posted. 
    No person shall throw, deposit, or distribute any handbill upon any private premises if requested by anyone thereon not to do so, or if there is placed on the premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof, a sign bearing the words: "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers Or Agents," "No Advertisement," or any similar notice advising that the occupants of the premises do not desire to be molested or have their right of privacy disturbed, or to have any handbills left upon such premises. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-14) 
Sec. 22-85. - Distributing handbills at private premises. 
(a)  No person shall throw, deposit, leave or distribute any handbill in or upon private premises except by handing or transmitting such handbill directly to the owner, occupant, or other person then present in or upon such private premises; provided, however, that in case of private premises which are not posted, as provided in section 22-84, such person may place or deposit any such handbill in or upon such private premises, if such handbill is so placed or deposited in a receptacle specifically designed to receive the same; this proviso shall not be interpreted to authorize the placing of handbills under or behind screens or entrance doors, on porches, in yards, or in mailboxes when so prohibited by federal postal law or regulations. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the distribution of mail by the United States, nor to newspapers (as defined herein) except that newspapers shall be placed on private property in such a manner as to prevent their being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-15) 
Sec. 22-86. - Dropping litter from aircraft. 
    No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit within the city any litter, handbill or any other object. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-16) 
Cross reference- Airport, ch. 4. 
Sec. 22-87. - Posting notices prohibited. 
    No person shall post or affix any notice, poster or other paper or device, calculated to attract the attention of the public, to any lamppost, street sign, traffic control device, public utility pole or public tree, or upon any private structure or building, except as may be required by law or authorized in writing by the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-17; Ord. No. 2587, art. 1, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 3164, art. 1, 5-5-03) 
Sec. 22-88. - Litter on occupied private property. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any private property within the city, whether owned by such person or not; provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the deposit or storage of litter in receptacles for collection. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-18) 
Sec. 22-89. - Owner of business to maintain premises free of litter. 
    The owner or person in control of a business shall maintain the property in such a manner that litter which is a result of his business operation will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any other private property. Owners or persons in control of a business shall keep their premises free from litter by picking up the litter at regular intervals and depositing this litter into receptacles. A regular interval shall be whatever period that is necessary to keep litter from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any other property but shall be not less than twice a day, provided, however, that this section shall not apply to the owner or operator of the business who at reasonable intervals collects and removes such litter which has been carried or deposited by the elements upon a street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-19) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, ch. 15. 
Sec. 22-90. - Throwing, depositing rock, metal, glass, wood, etc., upon private premises of another or upon public property; penalty. 
    No person shall throw or deposit in or upon another person's private premises or a public place litter which consists in whole or in part of rock, metal, glass, wood, masonry, hard plastic or other similar hard substances. Notwithstanding section 22-72, each violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment not exceeding three (3) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-20) 
Sec. 22-91. - Owner to maintain premises free of litter. 
    The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter. Provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in receptacles for collection. 
(Code 1967, § 16A-21) 
Sec. 22-92. - Control of runoff water; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to control the runoff of water from land possessed by him, or under his management or control, so that soil, dirt, gravel, rock, sand, trash, filth, or similar material, in an amount so as to constitute a nuisance, is carried upon a public sidewalk, street, or alley, or into publicly maintained drains or drainways. 
(b)  Any person who creates a nuisance on account of violation of section (a) above must abate that nuisance immediately whenever a duly commissioned police officer of the city determines that such nuisance is an immediate hazard for persons who travel upon said street, alley or sidewalk, or to the proper functioning of the drain or drainway. If a police officer makes that determination, he may order the responsible person to begin immediate clean-up and abatement of the nuisance, and should such person fail or refuse to comply with such police officer's order, the city shall have the right and authority to proceed to correct and remove said immediate hazard and charge the expense thereof to the person who is in violation of section (a) above. 
(c)  A person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day nor in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day for each day of such violation. Each and every day a person fails to abate such nuisance shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1807, art. 1, 10-16-95) 
Sec. 22-93. - Removal of mud, dirt, etc., from public streets; penalty. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation to whom a building, demolition, grading, stormwater or floodplain permit has been issued shall remove at least twice each working day any mud, dirt, sticky substance, litter or foreign matter of any kind carried into or deposited upon any public street, public sidewalk, or other public way or place of the city by any vehicle, or by the wheels of any vehicle, entering or leaving the site of the project for which the building, demolition, grading, stormwater or floodplain permit was issued. The removal shall be performed once prior to noon, and once at the end of the working day. 
(b)  Any landowner involved in building construction, demolition, or grading shall remove at least twice each working day any mud, dirt, sticky substance, litter or foreign matter of any kind carried into or deposited upon any public street, public sidewalk, or other public way or place of the city by any vehicle, or by the wheels of any vehicle, entering or leaving the site of the project of the building construction, demolition, or grading. The removal shall be performed once prior to noon, and once at the end of the working day. 
(c)  If any person, firm or corporation referred to in sections (a) or (b) above shall fail or refuse to remove said mud, dirt, sticky substance, litter or foreign matter, within the times set forth hereinabove or when ordered to do so by a duly commissioned police officer of this city, the city shall have the right and authority to proceed to remove such substances and charge the expense thereof to such person, firm or corporation. 
(d)  A person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day nor in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day for each day of such violation. Each and every day a person fails to remove such substance shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1808, art. 1, 10-16-95)
